{{disputed|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox event | title = [[State Visit]] of [[Xi Jinping]] to [[United States]] | image = 邀请习近平和彭麗媛访问白宫的请帖.jpg | caption = An invitation for [[Xi Jinping]] and his wife, [[Peng Liyuan]], to visit the [[White House]] | date = September 22 to 28, 2015 | time = | venue = [[Seattle]], [[Washington D.C.]], [[New York City]] | blank_label = | blank_data = | website = }} {{Xi Jinping sidebar}} The '''2015 state visit of Xi Jinping to the United States''', which was from September 22 to 28, 2015, was the [[state visit]] of [[China]]'s [[paramount leader]] [[Xi Jinping]] to the [[United States]]. It was his seventh visit to the United States and his first visit after succeeding the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] in 2012. During the period of the visit, Xi attended the US–China Internet Industry Forum, visited the [[White House]] and met [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], and attended the 70th anniversary of the [[United Nations]].
==Background== Xi's visit occurred at a time of high tensions in [[China-US relations]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[David Shambaugh]] |script-title=zh:從習近平訪美觀察中美關係的十大指標 |url=http://www.nanzao.com/tc/international/14ff4b37318fb11/shen-da-wei-cong-xi-jin-ping-fang-mei-guan-cha-zhong-mei-guan-xi-di-shi-da-zhi-biao |newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]] |language=Chinese |accessdate=September 26, 2015 |date=September 23, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150926164353/http://www.nanzao.com/tc/international/14ff4b37318fb11/shen-da-wei-cong-xi-jin-ping-fang-mei-guan-cha-zhong-mei-guan-xi-di-shi-da-zhi-biao |archivedate=September 26, 2015 }}</ref> [[The Wall Street Journal]] quoted experts who said Xi's US visit was to promote local technology companies and to ask the US government to not retaliate in response to accusations regarding the People's Republic of China having engaged in hacking activities, but Beijing has repeatedly denied the allegations of the United States.<ref>{{cite news|title=China Seeks Out Unlikely Ally: U.S. Tech Firms|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-seeks-out-unlikely-ally-u-s-tech-firms-1442808042|accessdate=January 4, 2015|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Chinese Foreign Minister [[Wang Yi (politician)|Wang Yi]] said Xi's visit was to promote trust between the two countries.<ref>{{cite news|title=习近平今天开启访美行程 西雅图准备热情迎接|url=http://world.huanqiu.com/exclusive/2015-09/7541077.html|accessdate=September 26, 2015|newspaper=[[Global Times]]|language=Chinese|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref>
Before this visit, the United States [[Congressional-Executive Commission on China]] held a hearing on human rights. Experts and members of Congress in attendance called on President Obama to ask Xi Jinping to stop the persecution of [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]], [[Uyghurs]], religious groups, [[non-governmental organizations]], intellectuals, democracy advocates, and supporters of "universal suffrage" in Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite news|title=Urging China's President Xi To Stop State-Sponsored Human Rights Abuses|url=http://www.cecc.gov/events/hearings/urging-china's-president-xi-to-stop-state-sponsored-human-rights-abuses|publisher=Congressional-Executive Commission on China|date=September 18, 2015}}</ref>
Xi had previously visited the United States six times. His first visit was as part of a corn industry delegation to the state of [[Iowa]] in 1985.<ref>{{cite news|title=Name-card from Xi Jinping's first visit to US 30 years ago goes viral|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/1860256/name-card-xi-jinpings-first-visit-us-goes-viral|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref> His most recent visit in 2013 was informal, in which he went to [[Sunnylands]] in [[California]], and met with US President [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite news|title=给留学生寄贺卡、老友叙旧：回顾习近平6次访美|url=http://news.qq.com/a/20150917/069937.htm?qqcom_pgv_from=aio|publisher=qq.com|date=September 17, 2015}}</ref>
==Process==
===September 22: Arrival at Seattle and Speech Giving=== On September 22, 2015, [[Xi Jinping]], and his wife, [[Peng Liyuan]], arrived at [[Paine Field]] and stepped off an [[Air China]] aircraft at about 9:30 am (Pacific Daylight Time). Before his arrival at the [[Westin Hotels & Resorts|Westin Seattle Hotel]], protesters gathered downtown to highlight the Chinese government's human rights abuses and to voice other concerns, including [[Falun Gong]] practitioners. Supporters of Xi were also present with Chinese flags. The protesters dispersed by 6:00 pm.<ref name="Day1">{{cite news|title=Live updates from Xi visit: Xi greeted by supporters, protesters upon arrival in Seattle |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/chinas-president-xi-arriving-this-morning/|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref>
In the evening, Xi attended a banquet speech at the Westin Seattle Hotel, meeting with Governor of Washington State Jay Inslee, Mayor of Seattle Ed Murray, Senator Patty Murray, Congressman Rick Larsen, and former US Ambassador to China Gary Locke. In his speech, he mentioned several contentious issues in China–US relations, including on [[cybersecurity]] and China's economy. Xi's speech cited elements of [[Culture of the United States|American culture]], included ''[[Sleepless in Seattle]]'' and the poet [[Walt Whitman]]. He also talked about his teenage years working on a farm in [[Yanchuan County]], Shaanxi, China, during the [[Cultural Revolution]]. He linked this to the [[Chinese Dream]], an individual work ethic which would strengthen the Chinese nation as a whole. Xi reiterated that China is against [[currency war]]s and will not lower the [[renminbi]] rate to boost exports.<ref name="Day1"/><ref name="economic reforms">{{cite news|title=Xi Jinping says China open to foreign business amid economic reforms |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-34332843|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=23 September 2015}}</ref> On the topic of his [[Anti-corruption campaign in China|anti-corruption]] reforms, Xi said, "It has nothing to do with a power struggle. In this case, there's no ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]''" – a reference to the [[Netflix]] political drama, which tops the list of most illegally downloaded shows in China.<ref name="Day1"/><ref>{{cite news|title=He said what? China's Xi Jinping makes 'House of Cards' joke |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/23/asia/xi-jinping-us-visit-house-of-cards/|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=23 September 2015}}</ref>
===September 23: Visiting and meeting business executives in Seattle=== [[File:習近平宣佈中國將購買300架波音飛機.ogv|thumb|right|Xi announced China will buy 300 Boeing aircraft.]] On the second day of his trip, Xi visited [[Boeing]] Everett factory and viewed the final assembly lines for the [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner]], [[Boeing 777]] and [[Boeing 747-8]]. Xi announced China will buy 300 Boeing aircraft, included 250 single-aisle [[Boeing 737]]s and 50 widebody jets for US$38 billion and build its first factory in [[Zhoushan]], [[Zhejiang]], China. It will be Boeing's first non-US factory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Boeing touts China orders and plant plans|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f769c924-615e-11e5-9846-de406ccb37f2.html#axzz3rM89r2Bv|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|date=23 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Boeing Hosts China President Xi Jinping, Announces Airplane Sales, Expanded Collaboration with China's Aviation Industry|url=http://boeing.mediaroom.com/2015-09-23-Boeing-Hosts-China-President-Xi-Jinping-Announces-Airplane-Sales-Expanded-Collaboration-with-Chinas-Aviation-Industry|publisher=Boeing|date=23 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="BC">{{cite news|title=China inks big deals with Boeing, Cisco Systems|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/09/23/china-buy-300-boeing-planes/72681578/|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=24 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Day2">{{cite news|title=Live updates on Xi's visit: Xi invites 100 Tacoma students to China |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/live-updates-on-xis-visit-wednesday-means-business/ |newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=September 23, 2015 }}</ref> The Chinese company [[Inspur]] and [[Cisco Systems]] said they will jointly sell networking technologies and products in China.<ref name="BC"/>
After his Boeing visit, Xi attended an Internet industry forum held at the headquarters of [[Microsoft]], located in [[Redmond, Washington|Redmond]]. He said China would prioritize Internet security and defended self-governance at the country level with respect to Internet regulations. Thirty US and Chinese technology executives attended this forum and posed for a photo with Xi and Chief of the State Internet Information Office [[Lu Wei (politician)|Lu Wei]], including [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] CEO [[Tim Cook]], [[Amazon.com]]'s CEO [[Jeff Bezos]], [[Alibaba Group|Alibaba]]'s CEO [[Jack Ma]], and Microsoft's CEO [[Satya Nadella]]. Executives from [[Google]] and [[Uber (company)|Uber]], did not appear in this photo.<ref name="Internet security">{{cite news|title=Internet security a priority, Chinese president tells tech executives |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/technology/china-us-tech-leaders-show-divergent-views-on-internet-interests/|newspaper=Seattle Times|date=23 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Missing from the US-China tech summit class photo: Uber, Google, and women|url=http://qz.com/509683/uber-google-and-women-were-conspicuously-absent-from-the-us-china-tech-meet/|publisher=QUARTZ|date=23 September 2015}}</ref> Before photographing, Facebook Chief Executive [[Mark Zuckerberg]] spoke to Xi in Mandarin.<ref name="Internet security"/> On September 21, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that technology executives were recommended to attend this forum, or risk their companies facing greater regulatory scrutiny in China.<ref>{{cite news|title=No soft landing as Chinese President Xi begins state visit|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/no-soft-landing-for-chinas-president-as-tension-builds-over-state-visit/2015/09/21/43164ea6-5e1c-11e5-9757-e49273f05f65_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=21 September 2015}}</ref>
Xi also visited Microsoft, where he met with [[Bill Gates|Bill]] and [[Melinda Gates]] as well as senior executives and board members of the company. He had the opportunity to preview new technologies being developed by Microsoft. Nadella gifted him a [[3D printing|3D printed]] model of the ''Liulinhai'', the first Chinese ship to dock in the United States, in Seattle, in 1979 after the establishment of diplomatic relations between the US and the People's Republic of China.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese President Xi Jinping visits Microsoft, sees potential of new technology|url=http://news.microsoft.com/features/chinese-president-xi-jinping-visits-microsoft-sees-potential-of-new-technology/|publisher=Microsoft|date=September 23, 2015}}</ref>
In the afternoon, Xi Jinping visited [[Lincoln High School (Tacoma, Washington)|Lincoln High School]] in [[Tacoma, Washington]]. He provided opportunities for students to experience Chinese music, government and culture.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lincoln High School Abes prep for President Xi Jinping of China|url = http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/education/article35990067.html|accessdate = September 22, 2015|date = September 21, 2015|newspaper=[[The News Tribune]]|publication-place = Tacoma, Washington}}</ref> Lincoln's football players presented Xi with a Lincoln Abes jersey emblazoned with the number "1". Xi reciprocated with gifts of books and ping-pong equipment. He also invited 100 Lincoln High students to visit China in 2016. During this visit, the adherents of Falun Gong and Vietnamese protesters held up signs such as "Stop Red China's Violations" and shouted slogans such as "Down with Red China".<ref name="Day2"/>
Xi attended a forum hosted by the Paulson Foundation, an economic think tank founded by [[Henry Paulson]].<ref>{{cite news|title=China President Xi Jinping meets with Big Tech execs |url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/09/23/news/companies/xi-jinping-tech-leaders/|publisher=[[CNN Money]]|date=September 23, 2015}}</ref> He also attended a dinner organized by local Chinese.<ref>{{cite news|title=習近平西雅圖出席美國僑界歡迎晚宴 僑胞感慨萬分 |url=http://www.uscnd.com/article/article-c187509.aspx |accessdate=September 27, 2015 |newspaper=環球通訊社 |date=September 26, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150927111204/http://www.uscnd.com/article/article-c187509.aspx |archivedate=September 27, 2015 }}</ref>
===September 24: Arrival at Washington D.C.=== Xi and Peng left Seattle and flew to Washington, D.C. on September 24.<ref name="Day2"/> They arrived at [[Joint Base Andrews]] and were greeted by United States Vice President [[Joe Biden]]. After greeting, a band played the US and Chinese national anthems. Then Xi and Obama had a private working dinner at the [[Blair House]].<ref>{{cite news|title=China's Xi arrives in Washington DC for first state visit |url=http://www.dw.com/en/chinas-xi-arrives-in-washington-dc-for-first-state-visit/a-18740613 |newspaper=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref>
===September 25: Meeting US President Barack Obama and State Dinner=== [[File:Biden Raises a Toast in Honor of Chinese President Xi.jpg|thumbnail|Xi Jinping and US Vice President Joe Biden raised a toast at a State Dinner]] [[File:Chinese President Xi Signs Secretary Kerry's Guestbook.jpg|thumbnail|Xi Jinping signed in Secretary of State [[John Kerry]]'s Guestbook]] On September 25, Xi Jinping arrived at the [[White House]]. [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] welcomed Xi's visit. After the welcoming ceremony, Xi and Obama held their discussion in the White House. During this discussion, they mentioned peacekeeping, nuclear security, health, environment, cybersecurity, law enforcement and counterterrorism. Xi said that China would develop a "national carbon emissions trading market" in 2017, as a part of climate change statement.<ref>{{cite news|title=President Obama Welcomes Chinese President Xi Jinping At The White House|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/obama-xi-jingping_560548eae4b0af3706dbd8dd|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Barack Obama and Xi Jinping meet at White House|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/11891414/Barach-Obama-and-Xi-Jinping-meet-at-White-House-live.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=FACT SHEET: President Xi Jinping's State Visit to the United States|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/09/25/fact-sheet-president-xi-jinpings-state-visit-united-states|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref> Later they held a news conference at Rose Garden. Obama and Xi reached a "common understanding" that neither the United States nor China should engage in state-sponsored cyberintrusions, and they would together seek the rules for appropriate conduct in cyberspace.<ref>{{cite news|title=Obama and Xi Jinping of China Agree to Steps on Cybertheft|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/26/world/asia/xi-jinping-white-house.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref>
In the evening, Obama held a state dinner for Xi Jinping. It was Obama's second state dinner for a Chinese President. The White House invited [[Anita Lo]], an Asian-American chef, to serve as a guest chef and to design the menu with Chinese elements. This state dinner's guests included US technology executives like Mark Zuckerberg, Tim Cook and Larry Ellison, and former Secretary of State [[Madeleine Albright]]. Obama said that China and the US together are "stronger when we accept the diversity of the views and the contributions and uphold the rights of all our people".<ref>{{cite news|title=State Dinner for Xi Jinping Has High-Tech Flavor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/26/world/asia/state-dinner-for-xi-jinping-has-high-tech-flavor.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Obama Hosts Lavish State Dinner for China's President Xi Jinping|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/obama-hosts-lavish-state-dinner-chinas-president-xi-jinping-n434126|publisher=NBC News|date=September 25, 2015 }}</ref>
===September 26: UN Sustainable Development Summit=== On September 26, Xi Jinping flew to [[New York City]] and attended the UN Sustainable Development Summit at the [[Headquarters of the United Nations]]. In his speech, he foresaw that "the world would seek an equitable, open, comprehensive and innovation-driven development path in an effort to achieve common development of all countries after 2015". He also announced the establishment of a [[South–South cooperation]] assistance fund. China will contribute US$2 billion to the fund to encourage developing countries to undertake the post-2015 development agenda. In addition, Xi has floated many important initiatives, such as the [[BRICS Development Bank]], the [[Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank]], and the [[Silk Road Fund]].<ref>{{cite press release|title=Xi Jinping Delivers Important Speech at UN Sustainable Development Summit, Stressing to Realize Common Development of All Countries from New Starting Point of Post-2015 Development Agenda|url=http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/zxxx_662805/t1302359.shtml|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|date=September 27, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese President Xi Jinping Addresses UN Sustainable Development Summit|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-09/27/c_134663354.htm|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=September 27, 2015 }}</ref>
During this visit, over 100 protesters held banners near the Headquarters of the United Nations, the Chinese consulate in New York City, the Chinese permanent mission to the UN, and Xi's hotel, the [[Waldorf Astoria New York]]. They called for Xi to prosecute the former leader of the Chinese Communist Party [[Jiang Zemin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Banners Calling for Justice Follow China's Xi Jinping to New York City|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/1776370-banners-calling-for-justice-follow-xi-jinping-to-new-york-city/|newspaper=[[Epoch Times]]|date=September 26, 2015 }}</ref>
===September 27: Global Women's Summit and Environmental issues=== On September 27, Xi Jinping and United Nations Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] co-hosted the "2015 Global Women's Summit". In his speech, Xi said, "As the Chinese people pursue a happy life, all Chinese women have the opportunity to excel in life and make their dreams come true".<ref name=cnbc/> He also announced China would contribute USD $10 million to [[UN Women]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Xi Jinping Vows to 'Reaffirm' China's Commitment to Women's Rights|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/28/world/asia/china-united-nations-womens-rights.html?_r=0|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 27, 2015 }}</ref> However, former Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] criticized his attendance, considering women's rights abuses in China.<ref name=cnbc>{{cite news|title=Do women hold up half of China's sky? Clinton disagrees|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/28/xi-chairs-un-women-conference-sparks-criticism-from-hillary-clinton.html|publisher=[[CNBC]]|date=September 28, 2015 }}</ref>
Peng Liyuan attended UNESCO's Special Envoy for the Advancement of Girls' and Women's Education. Peng spoke in English, the first time she showed her fluency in the language to a large gathering.<ref name=peng/> She said her Chinese Dream is that "all children especially girls can have access to good education".<ref name=peng>{{cite news|title=China's first lady Peng Liyuan impresses with fluent English speech at United Nations|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/1861780/chinas-first-lady-peng-liyuan-impresses-fluent-english?page=all|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=September 27, 2015 }}</ref>
Xi also attended the Leaders Working Lunch on Climate Change of the UN. He said China will control greenhouse gas emissions and put "China's South–South Cooperation Fund on Climate Change" into operation.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Xi Jinping Attends Leaders Working Lunch on Climate Change of UN|url=http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/zxxx_662805/t1302738.shtml|publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China]]|date=September 28, 2015 }}</ref>
===September 28: Speech at UN General Assembly=== Xi gave a speech at the General Debate of the 70th Session of the [[United Nations General Assembly]]. He mentioned the [[2015 China Victory Day Parade|commemoration of the 70th anniversary of Victory over Japan Day of the Second World War in China]] and emphasized that commemorating history is not revenge. Xi also said all economies should be built on an eco-environment, and green, low-carbon circular sustainable development platform. He also pledged US$100 million, over a period of five years, to the [[African Union]].<ref>{{cite news|title=China's President Pledges $1 Billion To United Nations For 'Peace And Development'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/xi-jinping-united-nations_560724c6e4b0af3706dc92df|newspaper=[[The World Post]]|date=September 28, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=China: H.E. Mr. Xi Jinping, President|url=https://gadebate.un.org/70/china|publisher=[[General Assembly of the United Nations]]|date=September 28, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite video|date=2015-09-28|title=General Assembly: 12th and 13th plenary meetings - General Debate (28 September - 3 October 2015)|agency=United Nations Web TV}}</ref>

'''Abdul Rashid''' ({{lang-ar| عبد الرشيد}}) is a male Muslim given name, and in modern usage, surname. It is built from the Arabic words ''[[Abd (Arabic)|Abd]]'', ''[[al-]]'' and ''[[Rashid (name)|Rashid]]''. The name means "servant of the right-minded", ''Ar-Rashīd'' being one of the [[names of God in the Qur'an]], which give rise to the [[List of Arabic theophoric names|Muslim theophoric names]].<ref name=ahmed>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author=Salahuddin Ahmed| publisher = Hurst & Company| location=London| year=1999}}</ref><ref name=rahman>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author= S. A. Rahman| publisher=Goodword Books| location=New Delhi| year=2001}}</ref>
The letter ''a'' of the ''al-'' is unstressed, and can be transliterated by almost any vowel, often by ''u''. Because the letter ''r'' is a [[sun and moon letters|sun letter]], the letter ''l'' of the ''al-'' is assimilated to it. Thus although the name is written in Arabic with letters corresponding to ''Abd al-Rashid'', the usual pronunciation corresponds to ''Abd ar-Rashid''. Alternative transliterations include ''‘Abd ar-Rasheed'' and others, all subject to variable spacing and hyphenation.
The closely related name '''Abdel Raashid''' ({{lang-ar| عبد الراشد}}) is difficult to distinguish from the other in transliteration.
It may refer to:
==Politicians== *Maulana [[Abdur Rashid Tarkabagish]] (1900–1986), Bangladeshi politician *[[Sardar Abdur Rashid Khan]] (1906 - ?1995), senior police officer and cabinet minister in Pakistan *[[Abdirashid Ali Shermarke]] (1919–1969), Prime Minister of Somalia *[[Chauhdry Abdul Rashid]] (born 1941), Pakistani-British politician *[[Maher Abd al-Rashid]], (born 1942) Iraqi General *[[Abdul Rashid Shaheen]] (born 1945), Indian politician *[[Abdul Rasheed Hussain]] (born 1946), Maldivian politician *[[Abdul Rashid Dostum]] (born 1954), Afghan soldier and politician *[[Abderrachid Boukerzaza]] (born 1955), Algerian politician *[[Abdirashid Mohamed Hidig]], Somali politician *[[Abdur Rasheed Turabi]], politician in Azad Jammu & Kashmir *[[Abdul Rashid Godil]] (born 1960), Pakistani politician *[[Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke]] (born 1960), Prime Minister of Somalia
==Sports== *[[Lala Abdul Rashid]] (1922–1988), member of Pakistan's 1960 Olympics field Hockey team *[[Muhammad Abdul Rashid]] (born 1941), Pakistani Olympic silver medallist in field hockey *[[Abdul Rasheed Baloch]] (born 1972), Pakistani boxer *[[Abdul Rashid Qambrani]] (born 1975), Pakistani boxer *[[Mohd Rafdi Abdul Rashid]] (born 1977), Malaysian footballer *[[Abdul Rashid (hurdler)]] (born 1979), Pakistani Olympic sprint hurdler
==Others== *[[Qais Abdur Rashid]] (575 - 661), legendary ancestor of the Pashtun race *[[Abdurashid Khan]] (1508–1560), ruler of Yarkand Khanate in Uyghurstan (Eastern Turkestan) *[[Abdurreshid Ibrahim]] (1857-1944), Russia-born Tatar Muslim scholar, journalist, and traveller *[[Abdul Rashid (judge)]] (1889–1981), Chief Justice of Pakistan *[[Abdur Rashid Kardar]] (1904–1989), Pakistani actor and director *[[Abdul Rashid Khan]] (born 1908), Indian musician *[[Abdul Rashid (agriculturist)]] (born 1950), Pakistani Agricultural Scientist and Bioscientist *[[Abdul Rashid Ghazi]] (ca. 1964 −2007), Pakistani Muslim cleric *[[Abdirashid Duale]], Somali businessman

1966–1999 (Army) | rank = [[General]] | unit = | commands = | battles = | awards = }} '''Abdulsalami Abubakar''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|ɑː|b|d|əl|s|ə|ˈ|l|æ|m|i|_|ˌ|ɑː|b|u|ˈ|b|ɑː|k|ɑːr|audio=En-us-Abdulsalami Abubakar from Nigeria pronunciation (Voice of America).ogg}}; born June 13, 1942) is a retired Nigerian Army General who was [[Nigerian military juntas of 1966–79 and 1983–98|Military Head of State]] from 9 June 1998 until 29 May 1999. He succeeded [[Sani Abacha]] upon Abacha's death. During his leadership, Nigeria adopted a modified version of the 1979 constitution, which provided for multiparty elections. He transferred power to president-elect [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] on 29 May 1999. ==Early life== Abubakar was born on 13 June 1942 to his father Abubakar Jibrin and his mother Fatikande Mohammed, in [[Minna]], [[Niger State]], Nigeria. From 1950-1956 he attended Minna Native Authority Primary school. From 1957-1962, he had his secondary school education at Government College, Bida, Niger state. From January to October 1963 he studied at Kaduna Technical College. ==Military careers== ===Air force career=== Abubakar is a member of the pioneering sets of officer cadets who enlisted into the Nigerian Air force on 3 October 1963. From 1964- 1966, he was flown to [[Uetersen]], Western Germany with a team of officer cadets, for Basic and Advance Military Training. When he returned to Nigeria in 1966 he was seconded to the Nigeria Army.{{cite web|url=http://politicoscope.com/2015/04/18/nigeria-abdulsalami-abubakar-biography-and-profile/ |title=nigeria abdulsalami abubakar biography and profile }} ===Army career=== After joining the army in 1966 as an officer cadet, Abubakar attended the emergency combatant short service course two. In October 1967, Abubakar was commissioned second lieutenant, infantry division, Nigerian army. From 1967-1968, Abubakar was general staff officer two, second garrison, and commanding officer, 92 infantry battalion from 1969-1974. Between 1974 and 1975, he was made brigade major, 7th infantry brigade. In 1975 he served as commanding officer, 84 infantry battalion. In 1978-1979, Abubakar was commanding officer for the 145 infantry battalion (NIBATT II), United Nations Interim force, Lebanon. In 1979 he was made assistant adjutant general 3rd Infantry division, Nigeria. From 1980-1982, Abubakar was chief instructor at the Nigerian Defence Academy. In 1982 he was appointed as the colonel of administration and quartering, 1st mechanised division. A position he held up until 1984. From 1985-1986, Abubakar was the commander 3rd mechanised brigade. He served as the military secretary of the army, 1986–1988. Abubakar was made general officer commanding 1st mechanised division 1990-1991. Between 1991-1993, he was the principal staff officer, as the army chief of plan and policy, Defence Headquarters. From 1993-1998, the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, General [[Sani Abacha]] appointed Abubakar as the Chief of Defence Staff, Defence Headquarters. Upon Abacha’s death on 8 June 1998, Abubakar took power as the military president of Nigeria and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces on 9 June 1998. In May 1999 General Abubakar, handed over power to the newly elected civilian president, [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] and retired from the army.{{cite book |last= Obotetukudo| first=Solomon|title=The Inaugural Addresses and Ascension Speeches of Nigerian Elected and Non elected presidents and prime minister from 1960 -2010|publisher=University Press of America|year=2011|pages=121}} ==Presidency== [[File:Seal of the President of Nigeria.svg|thumb|right|[[Seal of the President of Nigeria|Seal of the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria]] ]] Nigeria had been ruled by military leaders since [[Muhammadu Buhari]] seized power from [[Shehu Shagari]] in a 1983 coup.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ni.html |title=Nigeria |accessdate=9 June 2007 |date=31 May 2007 |work=The [[World Factbook]] Online |publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gSwE0b5H?url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ni.html |archivedate=2 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Although democratic elections had been held in 1993, they were annulled by General Ibrahim Babangida. Reported to have had an initial reluctance to accepting the position, Abubakar was sworn in as president on 9 June 1998 after the unexpected death of Abacha. He declared a weeklong period of national mourning.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifex.org/alerts/layout/set/print/content/view/full/6444/ |title=Successor to General Sani Abacha appointed |accessdate=7 June 2007 |date=9 June 1998 |work=IFEX Alerts |publisher=[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005145336/http://www.ifex.org/alerts/layout/set/print/content/view/full/6444/ |archivedate=5 October 2012 }} A few days after assuming office, Abubakar promised to hold elections within a year and transfer power to an elected president. He established the [[Independent National Electoral Commission]] (INEC), appointing former Supreme Court Justice [[Ephraim Akpata]] as chairman.{{cite web |url=http://inecnigeria.org/index.php?cateid=9&contid=6 |title=INEC History |publisher=Independent National Electoral Commission |accessdate=13 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wWgOjfni?url=http://inecnigeria.org/index.php?cateid=9&contid=6 |archivedate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} The INEC held a series of elections first for Local Government Areas in December 1998, then for State Assemblies and Governors, National Assemblies and finally for the President on 27 February 1999. Although efforts were made to ensure that the elections were free and fair, there were widespread irregularities that drew criticism from foreign observers.{{cite web |url=http://www.cartercenter.org/documents/1152.pdf |title=OBSERVING THE 1998–99 NIGERIA ELECTIONS |publisher=Carter Center, NDI |date=Summer 1999 |accessdate=14 February 2010}} Surprising some critics of the country's military, Abubakar kept his word and transferred power to elected president Obasanjo on 29 May 1999. During his administration Nigeria adopted a new constitution May 5, 1999, which went into effect when [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] became president. ==Legacy== Abubakar's legacy is mixed. A lecture circuit at [[Chicago State University]] in Chicago, Illinois, United States featuring him encountered opposition, because he had supported Abacha's government.{{cite web |url=http://nigeriaworld.com/letters/2001/feb/182pr.html |title= NCP, North America, protests Abdulsalami Lecture Series|accessdate=7 June 2007 |work= |publisher=[[National Conscience Party]]|last= Akande|first=Laolu |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225521/http://nigeriaworld.com/letters/2001/feb/182pr.html |archivedate = 27 September 2007}} (Abacha's administration was notorious for its [[human rights in Nigeria|human rights]] abuses).{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/africa/july-dec98/nigeria_10-21.html |title=Interview with Abubakar |accessdate=7 June 2007 |date=21 October 1998 |work=Online News Hour |publisher=[[MacNeil/Lehrer Productions]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wWgPLzGl?url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/africa/july-dec98/nigeria_10-21.html |archivedate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} He was also sued in that country by other Nigerians who claimed he was responsible for the death of 1993 president-elect [[Moshood Kashimawo Olawale Abiola]], who died in custody after being prevented by the military from taking office, and for the violation of the rights of others during his administration.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php?id=80050 |last=Aboyade |first=Funke |title='Conflicting Court Orders in Abdulsalami Case Avoidable' |accessdate=7 June 2007 |work=Thisday Online |publisher=Leaders & Company Limited |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wWgQZhKX?url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php?id=80050 |archivedate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Abubakar helped in the Liberian peace movement by presiding over the 2003 peace talks between Charles Taylor and the opposing rebels. This is seen in the movie ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell''. ==Personal life== Abubakar is married to Fati and they have six children together.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlinenigeria.com/people/ad.asp?blurb=64 |title=Abdulsalami Abubakar |accessdate=7 June 2007 |work=Online Nigeria |publisher=Devace Nigeria |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wWgNAHmQ?url=http://www.onlinenigeria.com/people/ad.asp?blurb=64 |archivedate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ==Awards== Abudulsalami Abubakar has received several awards and medals. In alphabetical order they include: * Defence Service Medal (DSM) [[file:Defence Service Medal (Nigeria 1967-1970) - ribbon bar.png|40px|Defence Service Medal (Nigeria)]] * Distinguished Service Medal (DSM) * Forces Service Star (FSS) [[file:Forces Service Star (Nigeria) - ribbon bar.png|40px|Forces Service Star (Nigeria)]] * General Service Medal (GSM) [[file:General Service Medal (Nigeria) - ribbon bar.png|40px|General Service Medal (Nigeria)]] * Grand Commander of the Federal Republic of Nigeria (GCFR) [[File:Order of the Federal Republic (military) - Nigeria - ribbon bar.gif|40px]] * International Gold Medal, of the [[Economic Community of West African States]] * Meritorious Service Star (MSS) * National Service Medal (NSM) [[file:National Service Medal (Nigeria 1966-1970) - ribbon bar.png|40px|National Service Medal (Nigeria)]] * Republic Medal (RM) * [[Rainbow/Push Coalition]] Peace Prize * Silver Jubilee Medal (SJM) * [[Order of the Star of Ghana]] ==Bibliography== * Abubakar, Abdulsalami. (1998) ''[https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0006FDZZG/ Nigeria: A new beginning.]'' Publisher: [[Nigerian Federal Ministry of Commerce|Federal Ministry of Information and Culture]]. ASIN: B0006FDZZG ==See also== {{commons category|Abdulsalami Abubakar}} * [[Nigerian Third Republic]] * [[Nigerian Fourth Republic]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.onlinenigeria.com/people/ad.asp?blurb=64 Abdulsalami Abubakar – Famous Nigerians and personalities – OnlineNigeria.com] {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{S-bef|before=[[Sani Abacha]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[President of Nigeria|Chairman of the Provisional Ruling Council of Nigeria]]|years=1998–1999}} {{S-aft|after=[[Olusegun Obasanjo]]|as=President of Nigeria}} {{S-bef|before=[[Sani Abacha]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Economic Community of West African States|Chairman of the Economic Community of West African States]]|years=1998–1999}} {{S-aft|after=[[Gnassingbé Eyadéma]]}} {{S-end}} {{Nigerian Heads of State}} {{Chiefs of Defence Staff Staff (CDS) Nigeria}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abubakar, Abdulsalami}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Minna]] [[Category:Nigerian Muslims]] [[Category:Gbagyi people]] [[Category:Nigerian generals]] [[Category:Heads of state of Nigeria]] [[Category:Nigerian Air Force officers]] [[Category:Nigerian Army officers]]

He "played a prominent part in the revolution against the Shah",<ref name=CSM/> co-founding the Committee for the Defense of Freedom and Human Rights in 1977,<ref name=lexpress/> and was the campaign manager of [[Abolhassan Banisadr]] in the 1980 presidential election.<ref name=CSM>''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', 9 December 1980, [http://www.csmonitor.com/1980/1209/120932.html/%28page%29/2 Iran's militant clergy and moderates move to end bitter rivalry ]</ref> He was deputy minister of foreign affairs in 1979,<ref>Harvard Iranian Oral History Project, [http://ted.lib.harvard.edu/ted/deliver/~iohp/Salamatian,+Ahmad.01 Salamatian, Ahmad]</ref> and was elected to the [[Iranian parliament]] in February 1980.<ref name=HOSTF>[[House October Surprise Task Force]], [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015060776773;view=1up;seq=166 Joint report], p166</ref> He had lived in exile in France prior to the 1979 [[Iranian Revolution]] (gaining a [[Master of Advanced Studies]] in political science from the [[University of Paris]] in 1966), and returned there in September 1981 after Banisadr was deposed and assassination attempts were made against him.<ref name=lexpress>Dominique Lagarde and [[Delphine Saubaber]], ''[[L'Express]]'', 6 August 2009, [http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/monde/proche-moyen-orient/ahmad-salamatian-les-iraniens-aspirent-a-un-islam-du-possible_778869.html Ahmad Salamatian: "Les Iraniens aspirent à un islam du possible"]</ref><ref name=HOSTF/><ref>[[Arte]], 2 March 2012, [http://www.arte.tv/de/ahmad-salamatian-iranische-parlamentswahl-ist-inszenierung/6444756,CmC=6445966.html Ahmad Salamatian: Iranische Parlamentswahl ist Inszenierung] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923194350/http://www.arte.tv/de/ahmad-salamatian-iranische-parlamentswahl-ist-inszenierung/6444756,CmC=6445966.html |date=23 September 2015 }}</ref> He has written for ''[[Le Monde Diplomatique]]''.<ref>monde-diplomatique.fr, [http://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/recherche?s=Ahmad+Salamatian « Ahmad Salamatian » ]</ref>
Salamatian later said, in response to the release of the film ''[[Argo (2012 film)|Argo]]'', that he had been one of a number of Iranian officials aware of the 6 US hostages hidden in the Canadian embassy, who had kept quiet for fear of the radical hostage-taking groups.<ref>[[cbc.ca]], 19 August 2013, [http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/iran-hostage-canadian-caper-1979-rescue-no-secret-to-some-1.1357927 Iran hostage 'Canadian Caper' 1979 rescue no secret to some]</ref> In 2010 he co-authored a book on Iran's 2009-10 "[[2009–10 Iranian election protests|Green Revolution]]".

'''Antonio Vallejo-Nájera''' (1889–1960) was a Spanish psychiatrist. == Early life ==
Vallejo-Nájera was born in [[Paredes de Nava]] in 1889. He studied medicine at the [[University of Valladolid]] and joined the army’s sanitary corps in 1910, taking part in the [[Rif War]] between 1912 and 1915. During [[World War I]] he was posted to the military department at the Spanish Embassy in [[Berlin]]. There he met well-known figures of German Psychiatry such as Gruhle, Schwalb and [[Kraepelin]]. He also conducted inspections of prisoner of war concentration camps, an activity for which he was awarded medals by Belgium and France after the war. On returning to Spain he worked at the Ciempozuelos Military Psychiatric Clinic. When the Civil War broke out he was a teacher of Psychiatry in the Military Sanitary Academy.<ref>http://www.psychologyinspain.com/content/full/1997/1frame.htm</ref>
Vallejo Nájera promoted in Spain a personal notion of [[eugenics]], intending to reconcile German doctrines of [[racial hygiene]] from authors like Schwalb with the requirements of [[Catholic]] moral doctrine, opposed to state-imposed measures of eugenic restriction. He advocated ''eugamia'', a eugenic policy implemented through premarital orientation work based on the biopsychological assessment of a couple’s personality.<ref>http://www.psychologyinspain.com/content/full/1997/1frame.htm</ref>
== Spanish Civil War and Francoist repression== During the [[Spanish Civil War]] he supported the [[National faction (Spanish Civil War)|nationalists]]. In 1938, he set up the ''Gabinete de Investigaciones Psicológicas de la Inspección de Campos de Concentración de Prisioneros de Guerra'' (Psychological Research Bureau of Inspection of Prisoner of War Concentration Camps), a center for psychological investigations. The bureau was established near the San Pedro de Cardeña concentration camp and had fourteen clinics in the nationalist zone. Vallejo Najera carried out experiments on female [[Spanish Republican Army]] and [[International Brigades]] prisoners to establish "the bio-psychic roots of [[Marxism]]" and find the "red gene".<ref>Preston, Paul. ''The Spanish civil war. Reaction, revolution & revenge.'' Harper Perennial. 2006. London. p.310</ref><ref>http://www.psychologyinspain.com/content/full/1997/1frame.htm</ref> For Vallejo Najera, Marxists were genetic retards<ref>Tremlett, Giles. ''Ghosts of Spain.'' Faber and Faber. London. 2006. p.63</ref> and Marxism was a mental illness: "A priori, it seems probable that psychopaths of all types would join the Marxist ranks... Since Marxism goes together with social immorality... we presume those fanatics who fought with arms will show schizoid temperaments".<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/nov/01/spain.gilestremlett</ref>
Vallejo’s conclusions were that the only way to prevent the racial dissolution of the Spanish was to take away the ''red'' children from their mothers in places "away from [[Democracy|democratic]] environments and where the exaltation of [[Scientific racism|bio-psychic racial qualities]] is encouraged".<ref>Tremlett, Giles. ''Ghosts of Spain.'' Faber and Faber. London. 2006. p.63</ref> By 1943, 12,043 children had been taken from their mothers and handed over to orphanages or Francoist families,<ref>Beevor, Antony. ''The Battle for Spain; The Spanish Civil War 1936-1939'' Penguin books. London. 2006. p.407</ref> but the number of children taken away from their parents may be closer to 30,000.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/the-30000-lost-children-of-the-franco-years-are-set-to-be-saved-from-oblivion-2173996.html</ref> Furthermore, many children evacuated by the Republic to France, England and elsewhere, were forced to return against the will of their parents.<ref>Tremlett, Giles. ''Ghosts of Spain.'' Faber and Faber. London. 2006. p.63</ref> In some cases birth records were destroyed<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/01/world/europe/01franco.html</ref> and the children's names changed<ref>http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5802820.ece</ref> in order to prevent any further contact with their parents.
Vallejo Najera contributed to the justification of the Francoist post-war repression. He said that the ''[[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|reds]]'' should: "suffer the punishment they deserve, with death the easiest of them all. Some will live in permanent [[exile]]... Others will lose their freedom, groaning for years in prisons, purging their crimes with forced work in order to earn their daily bread...".<ref>Tremlett, Giles. ''Ghosts of Spain.'' Faber and Faber. London. 2006. pp.61-62</ref> According to Paul Preston the "investigations" of Vallejo-Najera provided the Francoist State with "scientific" arguments in order to "justify their views on the subhuman nature of their adversaries".<ref>Preston, Paul. ''The Spanish civil war. Reaction, revolution & revenge.'' Harper Perennial. 2006. London. p.310</ref> According to the Spanish psychiatrist Carlos Castillo del Pino: "For Vallejo Nagera, reds were degenerates and if they were allowed to breed they would enfeeble the Spanish race. Therefore, they had to be exterminated."<ref>http://vimeo.com/26232645</ref>
== Later life== When the Civil War ended, Vallejo's support for Francoism was rewarded by his appointment as Professor of Psychiatry at the [[Complutense University of Madrid|University of Madrid]]. "He became one of the most influential figures in Spanish Psychiatry and Psychology in the forties and fifties: his name is among the 16 founders of the Spanish Psychological Society."<ref>http://www.psychologyinspain.com/content/full/1997/1frame.htm</ref>
He died in 1960.<ref>http://www.psychologyinspain.com/content/full/1997/1frame.htm</ref>

'''Arnould Bonneville de Marsangy''', born in [[Mons]] in 1802 and died in 1894 to Paris was a French [[magistrate]].
He was a forerunner in the field of [[Criminology]] and originator of ideas such as the criminal (proposed in 1848 and introduced in 1850), [[parole]] (which he termed "preparatory liberations"),<ref>{{cite journal |last=Normandeau |first=André |title=Pioneers in Criminology: Arnould Bonneville de Marsangy (1802-1894) |journal=[[The Journal of Criminal Law, Criminology, and Police Science]] |publisher=[[Northwestern University School of Law]] |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=28–32 |url=http://scholarlycommons.law.northwestern.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=5565&context=jclc |quote=Bonneville delineated a parole system, which he called "preparatory liberation" or "conditional release", as early as 1846 when he delivered a discourse on the topic at the opening session of the Civil Tribunal at Reims.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title="Twenty-Third Annual Report of the Executive Committee of the Prison Association of New York for 1867" |date=January 29, 1868 |publisher=C. Van Benthuysen & Sons |pages=165–178 |authorlink=Arnould Bonneville de Marsangy |first=Arnould |last=Bonneville de Marsangy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kIs4AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA165}}</ref> the generalization of fines in lieu of imprisonment or compensation for victims of a miscarriage of justice, as well, as [[recidivism]].
==Books== * De la récidive, ou des moyens les plus efficaces pour constater rechercher et réprimer les rechutes dans toute infraction à la loi pénale, 1844 * Des libérations préparatoires, 1846 * Traité des diverses institutions complémentaires du régime pénitentiaire, 1847 * Des pénalités pécuniaires au double point de vue de la répression des méfaits et du soulagement des classes indigentes, 1847 * De l'amélioration de la loi criminelle en vue d'une justice plus prompte, plus efficace, plus généreuse et plus moralisante, 1855 1 * Étude sur la moralité comparée de la femme, et de l'homme, au point de vue de l'amélioration des lois pénales et des progrès de la civilisation, 1862
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=V3CNne6WnWgC&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=arnould+bonneville+1802+1894&source=bl&ots=vB2io7rvgr&sig=1eUUc_cZ_rHuJNkXHWFjcaL-SFs&hl=fr&ei=UMq-SfS0LtzFjAfejOiUCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result#PPA27,M1 Bonneville de Marsangy, 1802-1894 un précurseur de la science criminelle moderne, par Sylvaine Ruopoli-Cayet : GoogleLivres (aperçu limité)]

voice actor | years_active = 2000–present | children = Danesh and [[Kayoze Irani]] (sons) and Sanaya (daughter) }} '''Boman Irani''' (born 2 December 1959) is an [[India]]n film and theatre actor, voice artist and photographer of [[Irani (India)|Irani]] descent. He is widely known for his comedic and villain roles in [[Bollywood]] films such as ''[[Don (2006 Hindi film)|Don]]'', ''[[Munna Bhai MBBS]]'', ''[[3 Idiots]]'', ''[[Happy New Year (2014 film)|Happy New Year]]'', ''[[PK (film)|PK]]'' and ''[[Dilwale (2015 film)|Dilwale]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news18.com/news/movies/i-borrow-from-real-life-people-for-my-characters-says-boman-irani-1600431.html|title=I Borrow From Real-life People For My Characters, Says Boman Irani|work=News18|access-date=2018-01-06}} ==Early life== Irani was born on 2 December 1959, in [[Mumbai]]. He finished his schooling in [[St. Mary's School, Mumbai|St. Mary's School]], Mumbai. Irani was [[dyslexic]] and had [[ADHD]] and had a lisp.{{cite web|title=Josh talks - Boman Irani|url=https://www.youtube.com|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=Josh talks|accessdate=30 June 2017}} He overcame his lisp eventually. He undertook a two-year waiter course at [[Mithibai College]] in Mumbai. After his polytechnic diploma course, he joined the [[Taj Mahal Palace & Tower]] and worked there as a [[waiter]] and in room service.{{cite web|title=Boman Irani gets candid|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Boman-Irani-gets-candid/Article1-527275.aspx|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=20 February 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121104012/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Boman-Irani-gets-candid/Article1-527275.aspx|archivedate=21 January 2011|df=dmy-all}} He was promoted and finally worked as a waiter at the rooftop French restaurant, Rendezvous. He worked at the Taj Mahal for two years. ==Career as a boxing photographer== While he was at school, he would watch movies daily at the Alexander Cinema daily after school. His mother often encouraged him to watch the movies repeatedly, to observe their cinematography and art. Irani's father died three months before Irani was born, but had a farsan-making shop, which his mother took over thereafter. Irani also worked at this shop on Grant Road till he was 32 years old. This ancestral bakery and farsan shop was located in the [[Grant Road|Grant road]] area of Mumbai, between Novelty and Apsara Cinemas, and was also where he first met his wife. While working at the Taj, using the tips that he received, Irani bought a camera and took sports pictures (school cricket and football matches), selling them for twenty to thirty rupees, which he continued till well after marriage. His epiphany came when he saved money for seven years to take his family for their first ever vacation to [[Ooty]], but they ended up in a desolate run-down hotel called Shawham Palace. Irani decided to take control of his life, and instead of living the petty existence of a photographer selling small photos, he would started to dream and live big and provide more for his family. Irani calls it his "zero number bulb moment".{{cite web|title=From waiter to a rising star: Boman Irani|url=http://www.thegenxtimes.com/editorials/from-waiter-to-a-rising-star-boman-irani/|work=The GenX Times|accessdate=5 April 2017}} Irani continued to be a photographer, but now at the age of 32, went six months prior to the world boxing championships at Mumbai to meet Adajania, the then president of the Olympic boxing association of India, and requested to become the official photographer of the World Cup. When Adajania told him there was no need for him, Irani offered to work at his office for six months for free in return for a ring-side badge to cover the event. He continued to try to convince Adajania, and covered a state boxing match in a different manner than other photographers. Adajania was impressed by his photos and his passion and appointed Irani as the official photographer. Meanwhile, he became the photographer for the Norwegian boxing team and photographed specific photos that they needed of [[Ole Klemetsen]]. When asked about his charges, Irani asked for the international rate. Irani took the required photos with his [[Pentax K1000|K-1000]]. ==Career== Irani began his acting career in theatre and moved to films in 2000. Irani gained attention for his role in the 2003 comedy ''[[Munna Bhai M.B.B.S.]]''. He later appeared in ''[[Lage Raho Munna Bhai]]'' for which he received several [[International Indian Film Academy|IIFA]] award nominations and in ''[[3 Idiots]]'' opposite [[Aamir khan]] which earned him a [[Filmfare Award]] and a [[Star Screen Award]] for Best Actor in a Villainous Role.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} ===Theatre career=== Acting had been a passion to Irani during school and college days. He trained under acting coach Hansraj Siddhia from 1981 to 1983 and adopted professional acting methods. Irani's mentor was [[Alyque Padamsee]] — the veteran theatre actor best known for his role as [[Mohammad Ali Jinnah]] in ''[[Gandhi (film)|Gandhi]]''. He was introduced to Padamsee by [[Shiamak Davar]].{{cite web|title=The making of an actor |url=http://bomanirani.com/bi_theat.htm |publisher=Bomanirani.com|accessdate=20 February 2011}} Irani's earliest theatrical appearance was in ''Roshni'' where he played a cameo at the Regional Theatre in [[Versova, Mumbai|Versova]]. He followed this up with serials like ''Family Ties'' and ''Mahatma vs Gandhi'', playing [[Gandhi]] after the role was turned down by [[Darshan Jariwala]]. His most illustrious play to date is ''I am not Bajirao'' which ran for 10 years. ===Film career=== Irani started out in a number of advertisements such as [[Fanta]], [[CEAT Limited|Ceat]] and Krackjack biscuits (as Mr. Jack of the Krack and Jack duo).{{cite web|url=http://www.bomanirani.com/bi_ads.htm |title=Actor – Ad Films – India |publisher=Boman Irani |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011}} His small but significant role in ''[[Darna Mana Hai]]'' earned him acclaim. The film didn't fare too well, but his was one of the most remembered segments of the film along with [[Saif Ali Khan]]. With ''[[Munna Bhai M.B.B.S.]]'', Irani became popular. His role as J. Asthana earned him a [[Filmfare Award]] nomination for [[Filmfare Award for Best Performance in a Comic Role|Best Comedian]]. His comic as well as minor antagonist type role in ''[[3 Idiots]]'' is also still remembered. Irani has appeared in many comedic roles (''[[Main Hoon Na]]'', ''[[Lage Raho Munna Bhai]]'', ''[[Dostana (2008 film)|Dostana]]'', ''[[Khosla Ka Ghosla]]'', ''[[Waqt: The Race Against Time]]'', ''[[No Entry]]'', ''[[Housefull (2010 film)|Housefull]]'', ''[[Ek Main Aur Ekk Tu]]'', ''[[Housefull 2]]'' and ''[[Cocktail (2012 film)|Cocktail]]''), supporting roles (''[[Veer-Zaara]]'', ''[[Maine Gandhi Ko Nahin Mara]]'', ''[[Lakshya (film)|Lakshya]]'', ''[[Honeymoon Travels Pvt. Ltd.]]'', ''[[Sorry Bhai!]]'', ''[[Page 3 (film)|Page 3]]'', ''[[My Wife's Murder]]'') and negative roles (''[[Don: The Chase Begins Again]]'' '', [[Don 2: The King Is Back]]'', ''[[Eklavya]]''). He acted in his first Telugu film ''[[Attharintiki Daaredhi]]'' as the grandfather of [[Pawan Kalyan]]. Irani hosted the [[IIFA Awards]] with actor [[Ritesh Deshmukh]] in [[9th IIFA Awards|2008]] in [[Bangkok]], [[10th IIFA Awards|2009]] in [[Macau]], [[11th IIFA Awards|2010]] in [[Colombo]] and [[12th IIFA Awards|2011]] in [[Toronto]].[http://www.sify.com/movies/riteish-deshmukh-boman-irani-are-iifa-hosts-again-news-bollywood-jfsufjbbeib.html Riteish Deshmukh, Boman Irani are IIFA hosts again] He has been on ''[[Kaun Banega Crorepati]]'' with [[Sanjay Dutt]]. He also hosted the quiz show ''[[Bollywood Ka Boss]]''. Irani featured in OneTouch Glucose Meters TV commercials in 2015 with [[Simone Singh]].[http://www.mullenlowelintas.in/news/lowe-lintas-highlights-sweet-side-life-diabetic-onetouch/ LOWE LINTAS HIGHLIGHTS THE ‘SWEET’ SIDE IN THE LIFE OF A DIABETIC FOR ONETOUCH] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416124459/http://www.mullenlowelintas.in/news/lowe-lintas-highlights-sweet-side-life-diabetic-onetouch/ |date=16 April 2016 }} ==Personal life== Boman Irani is an [[Irani (India)|Irani]] and follows the religion of [[Zoroastrianism]]. He speaks English, [[Hindi]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], and [[Marathi language|Marathi]] fluently. Irani is a member of the Parsee Television Actors Community and is its secretary. He is married to Zenobia, with whom he has two sons, Danesh and [[Kayoze Irani]] and a daughter, Sanaya.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! {{Infobox person | name = Bradley Birkenfeld | birth_name = Bradley Charles Birkenfeld | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|02|26}} | birth_place = [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], U.S. | nationality = American | alma_mater = [[Norwich University]]
[[American Graduate School of Business]] | occupation = Private banker | known_for = [[UBS tax evasion controversies#Birkenfeld Disclosure: Birkenfeld Disclosure: 2007|2007 Birkenfeld Disclosure]] | criminal_charge = [[Conspiracy against the United States|Conspiracy to defraud the United States]] | criminal_penalty = 40 months at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Schuylkill|FCI Federal Penitentiary]] and [[US$]]30,000 fine }} '''Bradley Charles Birkenfeld''' (born February 26, 1965) is an American private banker, [[Felony|convicted felon]], and [[whistleblower]]. During the mid- to late-2000s, he made a series of disclosures about [[UBS|UBS Group AG]] clients, in violation of [[Banking in Switzerland|Swiss banking secrecy]] laws, to the U.S. government alleging possible [[Tax evasion in the United States|tax evasion]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/11/business/11ubs.html?dbk|title=Indictments Said to Be Possible in UBS Inquiry|last=Browning|first=Lynnley|date=10 November 2008|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=16 September 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/09/AR2008110902394.html?nav=rss_business|title=U.S. Given A Look at Swiss Bank Accounts|last=Hilzenrath|first=David S.|date=10 November 2008|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=16 September 2013}} Known as the 2007 "[[UBS tax evasion controversies#Birkenfeld Disclosure: 2005–2011|Birkenfeld Disclosure]]", the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] (DOJ) announced it had reached a [[deferred prosecution agreement]] with UBS that resulted in a [[United States dollar|US$]]780 million fine and the release of previously privileged information on American tax evaders.{{cite web|url=http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202428390609&UBS_to_Pay_780_Million_Fine_in_Tax_Case_Settlement#ixzz2f5xMv3S5|title=UBS to Pay $780 Million Fine in Tax Case Settlement|last=Baxter|first=Brian|publisher=American Lawyer|accessdate=16 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2009/February/09-tax-136.html|title=UBS Enters into Deferred Prosecution Agreement: Bank Admits to Helping U.S. Taxpayers Hide Accounts from IRS; Agrees to Identify Customers & Pay $780 Million|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|accessdate=16 September 2013}} In the [[United States]], he was convicted by the DOJ for a single charge of [[Fraud|fraud conspiracy]] and served 40 months in a [[List of U.S. federal prisons|federal penitentiary]] from 2010 to 2012 with a fine of $30,000. After he applied for [[Whistleblower protection in the United States|whistleblower status]] and protection, the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) awarded him a settlement of $104 million through their [[Whistleblower Office]].{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444017504577645412614237708|title=Whistleblower Gets $104 Million|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|author=Laura Saunders and Robin Sidel|date=September 11, 2012}} In [[Switzerland]], he is considered a criminal and is subject to arrest if he returns to the country for breaking [[Bank secrecy|bank–client confidentiality]] laws, a federal crime. ==Early life and education== Birkenfeld was born on February 26, 1965, in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], a suburb of Boston.{{cite web|url=http://www.whistleblowers.org/storage/whistleblowers/documents/Birkenfeld/commutation%20petition%20april%2015th%20final.pdf|title=Petition for Commutation of Sentence|date=April 15, 2012|publisher=Whistleblowers.org|format=PDF}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/15/AR2010051500089.html |title=Swiss Banker Turned Whistleblower Ended Up With a Prison Sentence |work=The Washington Post |first=David S. |last=Hilzenrath |date= May 16, 2010 |accessdate=July 6, 2012}} His father was a neurosurgeon. Birkenfeld attended [[Thayer Academy]], a prep school, and graduated from [[Norwich University]] in Vermont in 1988.{{cite news|last=Voreacos|first=David|title=Banker Who Blew Whistle Over Tax Cheats Seeks Pardon|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-24/ubs-banker-who-blew-whistle-on-swiss-secrecy-over-tax-cheats-seeks-pardon.html|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=25 August 2013}} Birkenfeld is Jewish, his paternal grandfather, Max, emigrated to the United States from Romania in 1922. He obtained a master's degree at the [[AGSB University|American Graduate School of Business]] in [[La Tour-de-Peilz]], Switzerland. ==Banking career== Birkenfeld began his career in banking in the [[Foreign exchange market|currency trading]] department of [[State Street Bank and Trust Company|State Street Bank & Trust]] in Boston. Birkenfeld claims that he first blew the whistle on illegal activities while at State Street, approaching the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) in 1994. The information did not lead to any indictments. He says that he turned down an offer to join the FBI after the incident, but that claim has been disputed.{{cite news|last=Voreacos|first=David|title=Banker Who Blew Whistle Over Tax Cheats Seeks Pardon|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-24/ubs-banker-who-blew-whistle-on-swiss-secrecy-over-tax-cheats-seeks-pardon.html|publisher=Bloomberg News|accessdate=20 January 2014}} In 1996, he was hired as a [[private banking|private banker]] at [[Credit Suisse]] before moving on to [[Barclays|Barclay's Bank]] in 1998. In October 2001, Birkenfeld began working at [[UBS]] in [[Geneva|Geneva, Switzerland]], again as a private banker offering [[wealth management]] services.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/26/business/fi-swiss26|title=He put a dent in tax evasion|last=Pfeifer|first=Stuart|date=October 26, 2009|work=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=July 6, 2012}} His principal job responsibility was to solicit wealthy Americans to move their assets to the bank, enabling them to hide their funds due to Switzerland's strict banking secrecy laws and thus avoid paying U.S. taxes.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1928897,00.html|title=Why Is the UBS Whistle-Blower Headed to Prison?|last=Stier|first=Ken|date=6 October 2009|accessdate=22 August 2013|publisher=Time Magazine}} According to Birkenfeld, UBS sponsored events like art shows and yacht races in the United States to attract wealthy people as potential clients.{{cite news|last=Hilzenrath|first=David S.|title=Swiss banker turned whistleblower ended up with a prison sentence|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/15/AR2010051500089_3.html|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=25 August 2013|date=16 May 2010}}[[File:UBS (18707986273).jpg|thumb|Birkenfeld worked at Swiss investment bank [[UBS]] from 2001 to 2005 as a private banker. |255x255px]] === Birkenfeld disclosure: 2005–2011 === {{Main|UBS tax evasion controversies#Birkenfeld Disclosure: 2007 |UBS#Tax evasion}} '''In United States''' After learning about [[UBS|UBS Switzerland AG]] dealings in the U.S., Birkenfeld resigned on October 5, 2005 and became a partner at Union Charter Ltd., where he specialized in wealth management.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aLI2YNVAxDLM|title=Ex-UBS Banker Birkenfeld Pleads Guilty in Tax Case (Update3)|last=Carlyn|first=Kolker and David Voreacos|date=19 June 2008|accessdate=29 August 2013|publisher=Bloomberg}} In 2007, he disclosed to the U.S. [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] (DOJ) what he knew about UBS's illegal practices attempting to take advantage the [[Tax Relief and Health Care Act of 2006]], a law that could pay him up to 30% of any tax revenue recouped by the IRS.{{cite news |url=http://www.investmentnews.com/article/20090303/REG/903039966 |title=Justice Dept. chastises UBS chairman over IRS fraud probe |work=Investment News |first=Neil |last=Roland |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=July 7, 2012}} However, because he did not provide full and complete information to U.S. authorities, Birkenfeld was arrested in Boston on 7 May 2008 when he deplaned from Switzerland arraigned at the U.S. District Court, Southern District of Florida on 13 May.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1928897,00.html |title=Why is the UBS Whistle-Blower Headed to Prison? |work=Time Magazine |first=Ken |last=Stier |date=October 6, 2009 |accessdate=July 7, 2012}} Birkenfeld resigned his position with Union Charter on 3 June 2008 after agreeing to plead guilty to not disclosing accurate information. As a private banker, Birkenfeld advised California real estate developer [[Igor Olenicoff]], to evade U.S. taxes worth approximately [[United States dollar|US$]]200 million. Olenicoff subsequently pleaded guilty to [[tax evasion]] and paid a $52 million fine, but avoided a jail sentence.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a4Wgjok6Y_Ng |title=Ex-UBS Banker, Informant Birkenfeld Seeks Probe of Prosecutors |work=Bloomberg |first=David |last=Voreacos |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=July 7, 2012}} U.S. District Judge [[William Zloch]] charged him with a single count of [[Conspiracy against the United States|conspiracy to defraud the United States]] and sentenced Birkenfeld to 40 months in prison and a $30,000 fine.[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/08/21/UBS-whistle-blower-gets-40-month-sentence/UPI-12881250887037/ "UBS whistle-blower gets 40 month-sentence"], ''[[UPI]]'', Aug. 21, 2009. "The judge socked it to Birkenfeld ....". Retrieved 2012-09-12. Birkenfeld served his time at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Schuylkill|Schuylkill County Federal Correctional Institution]] from January 2010 to August 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10000872396390443687504577563220807465562|title=UBS Whistleblower Released From Prison|last=Sanders|first=Laura|accessdate=20 January 2014|publisher=Wall St. Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311084622/http://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10000872396390443687504577563220807465562#|archive-date=2016-03-11|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 2012, as a consequence of his whistleblower status, the U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) awarded him $104 million, 26% of the total $400 million in taxes returned.{{cite web|last=Ramonas|first=Andrew|title=Swiss Bank Whistleblower Wins $104M Reward from IRS|url=http://legaltimes.typepad.com/blt/2012/09/swiss-bank-whistleblower-wins-104m-reward-from-irs.html|publisher=The Blog of the Legal Times|accessdate=1 February 2013|date=September 11, 2012}} '''In Switzerland''' Birkenfeld is viewed as a criminal and a "[[Treason|traitor]]" by some members of the Swiss public and [[Banking in Switzerland|banking community]] as he broke the country's [[Banking in Switzerland#Modern secrecy|banking secrecy]] laws.{{cite news|last=Gonzalez|first=Juan|title=UBS whistleblower Bradley Birkenfeld deserves statue on Wall Street, not prison sentence|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/ubs-whistleblower-bradley-birkenfeld-deserves-statue-wall-street-prison-sentence-article-1.168809#ixzz2quw6PXA5|publisher=N.Y. Daily News|accessdate=20 January 2014|location=New York}} Although he left Switzerland before he disclosed banking client information, had he remained a resident, he would have been prosecuted by [[Zürich]] authorities for three and a half years in prison and commensurate fines. When asked if he would ever return to Switzerland, Birkenfeld stated: "I don't believe I will."{{Cite journal|last=Kroft|first=Steve|date=August 15, 2010|title=Banking: A Crack In the Swiss Vault|url=|journal=1|publication-date=May 13, 2018|volume=|pages=|via=CBS}} UBS announced that it would cease providing cross-border private banking services to U.S.-domiciled clients through its non-U.S. regulated units as of July 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/home/permalink/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20081112006425&newsLang=en|title=Statement on Indictment of UBS Executive|publisher=[[BusinessWire]]|accessdate=November 12, 2008}} After Birkenfeld's award, the Swiss newspaper ''[[Blick]]'' claimed, “Birkenfeld was a blessing for the Swiss financial industry,” in that his revelations helped accelerate the industry's transition away from its reliance on [[Money laundering|“dirty” money]] by dooming the bank secrecy laws that enabled tax evasion. Birkenfeld has compared the Swiss banking industry with [[Racket (crime)|gangsters]]. "In essence, bank secrecy is analogous to criminal racketeering — and the Swiss government, along with every Swiss private banker, is a co-conspirator." == Post-banking life: 2015–present == Brad Birkenfeld's three-year period of [[parole]] ran through November 2015; a year previous Birkenfeld's attorney petitioned the U.S. District Court to allow Birkenfeld to travel abroad.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102272941|title=Why this Swiss bank whistleblower can't leave US|last1=Javers|first1=Eamon|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=2 January 2015}} While on parole, Birkenfeld engaged with a variety of charitable efforts: he allowed disadvantaged children to use his luxury suite at [[Boston Bruins]] hockey games and donated six electric bicycles to the [[Boston Police Department]] after the [[Boston Marathon bombing]]s. In January 2015, Birkenfeld was [[Subpoena|subpoenaed]] by a French magistrate investigating the abetting of [[tax evasion]] and [[tax fraud]] by French citizens at UBS.{{cite web|last1=Letzing|first1=John|title=UBS Whistleblower to Assist French Investigation Into Swiss Bank; Bradley Birkenfeld Summoned to Appear Before Judge in Paris|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ubs-whistleblower-to-assist-french-investigation-into-swiss-bank-1423915866?mod=yahoo_hs|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=24 February 2015}} In February 2015, he was allowed to travel to France from 27 February to 1 March 2015 to appear before the French court.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-02-17/u-s-judge-gives-bradley-birkenfeld-ok-to-testify-in-ubs-probe|title=UBS Whistle-Blower Birkenfeld Allowed to Testify in France|last1=Voreacos|first1=David|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=24 February 2015}} The French court is investigating allegations that UBS marketed Swiss [[numbered bank account]]s to French citizens to allow them to hide their assets.{{cite web|last1=Lettzing|first1=John|title=Whistleblower Adds to UBS’s Tax Woes in France|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2015/02/18/whistleblower-adds-to-ubss-tax-woes-in-france/?mod=yahoo_hs|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=24 February 2015}} == See also == * [[Tax evasion in the United States]] * [[Banking in Switzerland]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birkenfeld, Brad}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Tax evasion in the United States]] [[Category:UBS people]] [[Category:Norwich University alumni]] [[Category:American people of Romanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:People from Brookline, Massachusetts]]

[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1987-1023-061, Berlin, 750-Jahr-Feier, Staatsakt, Honecker, Axen, Rodriguez.jpg|thumb|455px|Carlos Rafael Rodríguez (right) with [[Erich Honecker]] (left) and [[Hermann Lauter]] (center) in 1987]]
'''Carlos Rafael Rodríguez''' (May 23, 1913 – December 8, 1997) was a [[Cuba]]n [[Communist]] politician, who served in the cabinets of presidents [[Fulgencio Batista]] and [[Fidel Castro]].
Born in [[Cienfuegos]], he became [[mayor]] of the city when he was only 20. Four years later, he joined the [[Popular Socialist Party (Cuba)|Communist Party]] and was appointed editor of the party newspaper, ''Hoy''.<ref name=nytimes>Dillon.</ref> He graduated from university in 1939. Although he was a participant in the 1935 general strike against provisional President [[Carlos Mendieta]],<ref name=Suchlicki106>Suchlicki 106.</ref> in 1942, Rodríguez joined the cabinet of President [[Fulgencio Batista]].<ref>When he was Army Chief of Staff, Batista had forced President [[Ramón Grau]] to resign and appointed Mendieta president.</ref> A "dedicated Marxist", Rodríguez's participation in the Batista cabinet marked the high point of the regime's collaboration with the Communist Party.<ref name=Suchlicki106 />
Rodríguez first met [[Fidel Castro]] through a mutual friend after Castro visited the Communist Party's bookstore a few days before his disastrous attack on the [[Moncada Barracks]] on July 26, 1953.<ref name=Dominguez30>Domínguez 30.</ref> Although Rodríguez denounced the attack after it occurred,<ref name=nytimes /> he would eventually ally himself with Castro in the [[Cuban Revolution]]. In July 1958, he joined the [[26th of July Movement]] in the [[Sierra Maestra]] [[mountain range]] in support of its guerrilla war against Batista; it was the first such gesture of support by the Communist Party for the rebels.<ref name=Dominguez30 />
Castro befriended him, and after his victory, he rewarded Rodríguez with top posts in the Cuban government. From 1962 to 1965, Rodríguez headed the [[National Institute of Agrarian Reform]], and was referred to by some in the foreign press as Cuba's economic czar.<ref name=nytimes /> In 1969, Castro sent him as an "observer" to the [[1969 International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties|International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties]] in [[Moscow]], where he gave an important speech declaring that Cuba would "stand unflinchingly by the [[USSR]]".<ref>Suchlicki 153–4.</ref> The speech was one of a series of steps taken by the Castro regime to move closer to the Soviet Union after having publicly disagreed with the Soviets in the early- and mid-1960s. Rodríguez would remain a key figure in Soviet-Cuban relations, providing public statements during times of friendship and discord. Before being sidelined in 1997 with deteriorating health, he served on the [[Politburo]] and as Vice President. He suffered from [[Parkinson's disease]] and died in Havana, with Castro presiding over his burial ceremony.<ref name=nytimes />
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Domínguez, Jorge I. (1989). ''To Make a World Safe for Revolution: Cuba's Foreign Policy''. Cambridge, Massachusetts: [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|0-674-89325-5}}. *Suchlicki, Jaime (2002). ''Cuba: from Columbus to Castro and Beyond'', 5th Edition. Washington, D.C.: Brassey's. {{ISBN|1-57488-436-0}}. *Dillon, Sam (December 13, 1997). "[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/13/world/carlos-rodriguez-castro-ally-and-leftist-leader-dies-at-84.html Carlos Rodriguez, Castro Ally And Leftist Leader, Dies at 84]". ''The New York Times''. Retrieved on January 31, 2008.
{{Authority control}}
