{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Mohammed Hanzab | image = MOHAMMED HANZAB.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Mohammed Hanzab | order = | office = President, International Centre for Sport Security | term_start = 2011 | term_end = | predecessor = | successor = | birth_date = 1965 | birth_place = [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] | death_date = | birthname = | nationality = Qatari | spouse = | children = | alma_mater = [[Royal Air Force College Cranwell]] | residence = [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] }}
'''Mohammed Hanzab''' is the President of [[the International Centre for Sport Security]] (ICSS) in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]]. He is the former President of the Qatar International Academy for Security Studies and has an extensive background in defence.
==Early life and education== Born in Doha, Qatar (1965), Hanzab graduated from the British [[Royal Air Force College Cranwell]].
==Career== Hanzab is a former [[Lieutenant Colonel]] in the [[Qatar Armed Forces]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS to combat crime in sport|url=http://www.themiddleeastmagazine.com/news-detail.php?nid=31|publisher=The Middle East Magazine|accessdate=March 2012}}</ref> and has served as a commander of the Qatar Air Defence School and worked at the Qatar Air Defence Project, focusing on the advancement of secure communication, radar and C4i capabilities. Hanzab also undertook various senior roles for the Qatar Information Agency, including Director of Publications. He serves as President of the ICSS and is a former President of the Qatar International Academy for Security Studies (QIASS).<ref>{{cite web|title=International Sports Security Conference in Doha is Unique - Qatar is the First Country to Initiate International Sports Security Dialogue|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/755607/international-sports-security-conference-in-doha-is-unique-qatar-is-the-first-country-to-initiate-international-sports-security-dialogue|publisher=Canada Newswire|accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref>
==The International Centre for Sport Security== Mohammed Hanzab became President of [[The International Centre for Sport Security (ICSS)]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Securing Sport in Today's World|url=https://www.supersport.com/football/football-features/news/120423/Securing_sport_in_todays_world|publisher=Supersport|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref> in March 2011. The International Centre for Sport Security (ICSS) is an international, not-for-profit organisation based in Doha, Qatar. It was established in 2010 to act as a global hub of expertise in the field of safety, security and integrity for major sporting events. The ICSS’s key activities include advisory, training and research. It works primarily with organising committees,<ref>{{cite web|title=Biggies set to discuss security issues in Doha|url=http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar-sport/186922-biggies-set-to-discuss-security-issues-in-doha.html|publisher=The Peninsula|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> [[governments]], bidding nations,<ref>{{cite web|title=The ICSS signs agreement with Qatar 2022 Supreme Committee|url=http://www.aspirezone.qa/News/168.aspx|publisher=Aspire Zone|accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref> infrastructure owners, sport associations, [[Sports league|leagues]] and clubs. Hanzab was proud to launch the first international sport security journal in December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS launches sport security journal|url=http://www.securityblogs.co.uk/posts/tag/secretary/|publisher=Security Blogs|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> The ICSS also organises the annual conference, "Securing Sport",<ref>{{cite web|title=On the Scene – Securing Sport Kicks Off in Doha|url=http://www.moyadoddfootball.com/2013/03/on-the-scene-securing-sport-kicks-off-in-doha/|publisher=Moya Dodd Football|accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> first held in Doha in 2011,<ref>{{cite news|title=MFA represented at Doha conference|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110320/sport/mfa-represented-at-doha-conference.355688|accessdate=20 March 2011|newspaper=Times of Malta}}</ref> Qatar as well as the ICSS Expert Summit most recently held in Austria.<ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS hosts top experts at security summit|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/sport/192/details/352894/icss-hosts-top-experts-at-security-summit|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2013 ICSS Security Expert Summit kicks off in Vienna, Austria|url=http://www.sportsfeatures.com/olympicsnews/story/50284/2013-icss-security-expert-summit-kicks-off-in-vienna-austria|publisher=Sports Features|accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref> The Vice President of the ICSS is Qatari, Mohammed Hajaj Al Shahwani,<ref>{{cite web|title="Sport and Integrity" selected as new logo for SOP 2013-2014|url=http://www.qatarsports.co/2013/05/06/sport-and-integrity-selected-as-new-logo-for-sop-2013-2014/|publisher=Qatar Sports|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Shooting added to SOP calendar: QOC|url=http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/shooting/235792-shooting-added-to-sop-calendar-qoc-.html|publisher=The Peninsula|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> the Director General is German-born, [[Helmut Spahn]] formerly of [[FIFA]] and now a [[UEFA]] Security Officer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Doha-based ICSS to oversee 2012 Champs League final|url=http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar-sport/194541-doha-based-icss-to-oversee-2012-champs-league-final-.html|publisher=The Peninsula|accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref> Hanzab's advisory board members include: [[John Stevens, Baron Stevens of Kirkwhelpington|Lord John Stevens]], Eric Drossart, [[Khoo Boon Hui]], [[Rick Parry]], Dr Peter Ryan, [[Horst R. Schmidt]] and tennis star, [[Monica Seles]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Former tennis star Seles adds voice to sport-security body advisory board|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/latest/18510-former-tennis-star-seles-adds-voice-to-security-body-advisory-board|publisher=Inside the Games|accessdate=9 September 2012}}</ref>
== Qatar International Academy for Security Studies == In 2008 Mohammed Hanzab was appointed President of the Qatar International Academy for Security Studies (QIASS),<ref>{{cite web|title=International Sports Security Conference in Doha is Unique - Qatar is the First Country to Initiate International Sports Security Dialogue|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/755607/international-sports-security-conference-in-doha-is-unique-qatar-is-the-first-country-to-initiate-international-sports-security-dialogue|publisher=Newswire|accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> a professional institute that aims to raise security standards, knowledge, and cooperation within the [[Persian Gulf|Gulf region]] and across the world. QIASS serves multiple market sectors including governmental, commercial, and non-profit, across national, multinational, and international levels. Partners include global education and strategic policy organisations.<ref>{{cite web|title=QIASS study urges Interpol to combat radicalisation|url=http://legalift.wordpress.com/2010/11/13/qiass-study-urges-interpol-to-combat-radicalisation/|publisher=The Lift}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Mcevoy|first=Kieran|title=Countering ViolentExtremism: CommunityEngagementProgrammes In Europe|journal=Academia.edu|date=February 2012|url=https://www.academia.edu/1240164/QIASS_CVE_Paper_Phase_II_Paper_I}}</ref>
==Memorandums of Agreement== Hanzab has been called on<ref>{{cite web|title=Mohammed Hanzab: "Qatar Foundation se ha inspirado en la vida de Messi"|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/deportes/20110518/mohammed-hanzab-qatar-foundation-inspirado-vida-messi/1009801.shtml|publisher=El Periodico|accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> by a multitude of international media<ref>{{cite web|title=Governments failing to protect sport from crime - Security head|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17543699|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> on a variety of sport security, safety and integrity issues.<ref>{{cite web|title=MOHAMMED HANZAB (ICSS): EDUCATING TO SAFEGUARD THE INTEGRITY OF SPORT|url=http://www.leadersinfootball.com/blog/the-leader/mohammed-hanzab-icss-educating-to-safeguard-the-integrity-of-sport/|publisher=Leaders in Football|accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref> He has signed memorandums of understanding on the ICSS’ behalf with a number of organisations including: [[UNICEF]], [[UNESCO]], [[European Professional Football Leagues]], the [[Qatar Football Association]],<ref>{{cite web|title=QFA signs MoU with ICSS|url=http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/qfa-signs-mou-icss/|publisher=Doha Stadium Plus|accessdate=20 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325125451/http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/qfa-signs-mou-icss/|archivedate=25 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> the [[Organization of American States]], the European Lotteries<ref>{{cite web|title=THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRE FOR SPORT SECURITY (ICSS) SIGNS COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH EL|url=https://www.european-lotteries.org/announcement/international-centre-sport-security-icss-signs-cooperation-agreement-el?cf=4|publisher=The European Lotteries|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref> and Germany’s Institute for Fan Culture,<ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS announce new partnership with IfF|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/latest/16019-icss-announce-new-partnership-with-iff-|publisher=Inside the Games|accessdate=4 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS commits to research|url=http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar-sport/187208-icss-commits-to-research.html|publisher=The Peninsula|accessdate=15 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720195715/http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar-sport/187208-icss-commits-to-research.html|archivedate=20 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ESSMA,<ref>{{cite web|title=European Stadium & Safety Management Association|url=http://www.essma.eu/en/news/item/16-icss-announces-new-partnership-with-essma|publisher=Essma|accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref> the [[World Bank]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Centre for Sport Security Signs Cooperation Agreement With the World Bank Integrity Vice Presidency|url=http://www.virtualizationconference.com/node/2564765|publisher=Vitualization Conference|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> and a partnership agreement with [[Pantheon-Sorbonne University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Sorbonne vai propor regulamentação para as apostas ilegais no esporte|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/esporte/1061641-sorbonne-vai-propor-regulamentacao-para-as-apostas-ilegais-no-esporte.shtml|publisher=Folha De S.Paulo|accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ICSS announces new National Sport Integrity Index and Sorbonne-ICSS Handbook for Sport Integrity|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/press_releases/icss_announces_new_national_sport_integrity_index_and_sorbonne_icss_handboo/|publisher=Sports Pro|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> to combat breaches of sporting integrity including [[match-fixing]], with the duo most recently awarding an integrity award to the Badminton World Federation for their swift and resolute action in banning four Badminton doubles teams from the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games for match fixing.<ref>{{cite web|title=BWF’s London 2012 Stand for Integrity Saluted|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/sports/bwfs-london-2012-stand-for-integrity-saluted/|publisher=Jakarta Globe|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Badminton World Federation receives award for integrity|url=http://www.sportskeeda.com/2013/03/20/badminton-world-federation-receives-award-for-integrity/|publisher=Sports Keeda|accessdate=20 March 2013}}</ref> Hanzab also launched the Save the Dream programme with football star [[Alessandro Del Piero]],<ref>{{cite web|title=QOC announces ‘Save the Dream’ project|url=http://www.footballqatar.com/2012/09/qoc-announces-save-dream-project.html|publisher=Football Qatar|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref> awarding the first 'save the dream' award to Ivan Fernandez Anaya.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anaya wins first ‘save the dream’ award|url=http://www.dohastadiumplusqatar.com/anaya-wins-save-dream-award/|publisher=Doha Stadium Plus|accessdate=20 March 2013}}</ref> The first international 'save the dream' office was opened at Allesandro Del Piero's new Academy in [[Turin]], [[Italy]] in May 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Save the Dream Office to be Part of Alessandro Del Piero's Sporting and Cultural Centre|url=http://www.worldfootballinsider.com/Story.aspx?id=35806|publisher=World Football Insider|accessdate=23 May 2013}}</ref> Hanzab also headed a high-level meeting in collaboration with [[UNICRI]] on sport protection in the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ministry of the Interior of Qatar hosted high-level {{multiple issues| {{notability|bio|date=September 2014}} {{primary sources|date=September 2014}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Mona Vasquez | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = Mona Vasquez,
Cover of her book,
''Satan Created the Cult: Memoirs of an Escapee'' | birth_date = 1960 | birth_place = [[France]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[France|French]] [[author]],
anti-[[cult]]ist | salary = | networth = | spouse = | website = {{URL | http://mona.ateliere.free.fr }} | footnotes = }} '''Mona Vasquez''' (1960 – 2 September 2011) was a former [[Scientologist]] who was active in [[Scientology]]'s headquarters in Europe, in [[Copenhagen]], in the 1980s. She went on a [[hunger strike]] in August 1989 at Scientology's offices in [[Paris]] when she wanted to quit the program, in order to get her money back. She did receive almost €60,000 back from Scientology. Mona is a painter, and established{{cite news |last=Woljung |first=Eric |date=7 October 2004|title=Le monde de Mona Vasquez |url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2004/10/07/255987-le-monde-de-mona-vasquez.html |newspaper=La Depeche |location= |accessdate=19 September 2014 }} artist{{cite news |author= |title=L'artiste peintre Mona Vasquez inaugure la nouvelle galerie 113 |url= http://www.lindependant.fr/2011/05/13/l-artiste-peintre-mona-vasquez-inaugure-la-nouvelle-galerie-113,17651.php|newspaper=L'Independant |location= |date=13 May 2011|accessdate=19 September 2014 }} and poet.{{cite journal |last=Lamote |first=Thierry |date= |title=Par-delà la manipulation mentale : la violence insidieuse de l'église de scientologie |url=http://cairn.info/revue-topique-2010-2-page-177.htm |journal=Topique |publisher= |volume=2 |issue=111 |pages=177–195 |doi=10.3917/top.111.0177|accessdate=19 September 2014}} She has written an autobiography in which she recounts her experiences with Scientology, "Et Satan créa la Secte, Mémoires d’une rescapée". ==Experiences with Scientology== Vasquez says she was initially introduced to Scientology by reading a friend's books.[http://www.anti-scientologie.ch/temoignage-echomagazine.htm Echo Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618134347/http://anti-scientologie.ch/temoignage-echomagazine.htm |date=2006-06-18 }}, interview with Mona Vasquez, October 2004, "Scientology, a true control".
"The first time where I was challenged by the sect, it was by a friend. I was at the end of my second year in Art school in [[Toulouse]]. I read all kinds of books and the first contact was done thus, in 1982. I saw nothing suspicious and the brainwashing started." There, she says, she became part of an organisation under "tight control... from the mother church".{{cite web | first = John-Thor | last = Dahlburg | title = Report Urges Dissolution of Scientology Church in France | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2000/feb/29/news/mn-3701 | work = | publisher = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 2000-02-29 | accessdate = 2008-10-19 }} She says she attempted to leave three times in this period, always coming back.[http://prevensectes.com/mona1.htm prison sans barreaux, scientologie, sortir d'une secte] After being convicted of making illegal loans, which she argued had been encouraged by Scientology, she was set free from jail on the condition that she not attempt to contact members of the Scientology organisation.{{cite news |last=Mona |first=Vasquez |date=4 June 2004 |title=La prison sans barreaux |url=http://prevensectes.com/mona1.htm |newspaper=La Croix |location=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326080606/http://prevensectes.com/mona1.htm |archivedate=March 26, 2012|accessdate=19 September 2014 }} She finally rejected Scientology. With money tight, she sought the return of money she had paid to Scientology for books and training courses. After a ten-day hunger strike in Paris in August 1989 covered by [[France 2|Antenne 2]], the Scientology organization returned around ₣100,000 of her money to her. Since then, she has testified before the [[Parliamentary Commission on Cults in France]], and continued to paint and write. She died on 2 September 2011.{{cite web |title=Décès de Mona Vasquez |url=http://www.unadfi.org/deces-de-mona-vasquez.html |publisher=[[UNADFI]] |language=French |accessdate=13 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120915094916/http://www.unadfi.org/deces-de-mona-vasquez.html |archivedate=15 September 2012 |df= }} ==Publications== * ''Satan Created the Cult: Memoirs of an escapee'', ''La Secte: Et Satan créa la secte: Mémoires d'une rescapée'', Mona Vasquez, March 2006 * ''La secte : Comment je m'en suis sortie'', Mona Teulière (foreword by [[Jean Blum]]), ({{ISBN|978-2846590501}}) ==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} * [[Scientology]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{New Religious Movements}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vasquez, Mona}} [[Category:French-language writers]] [[Category:Former Scientologists]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:French activists]] [[Category:Critics of Scientology]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:French whistleblowers]] [[Category:Women whistleblowers]]

[[File:WilliamMRossetticonfiglie.jpg |thumb|Olivia in the left, the father [[William Michael Rossetti]] and daughters Olivia and Helen]] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use British English|date=April 2013}} {{More footnotes|date=April 2011}} '''Olivia Rossetti Agresti''' (30 September 1875 – 6 November 1960) was a British activist, author, editor, and [[interpreting|interpreter]]. A member of one of England's most prominent artistic and literary families, her unconventional political trajectory began with [[anarchism]], continued with the [[League of Nations]], and ended with [[Italian fascism]]. Her involvement with the latter led to an important correspondence and friendship with [[Ezra Pound]], who mentions her twice in his ''[[The Cantos|Cantos]]''.
== Anarchism ==
Olivia Rossetti Agresti was born in London to [[William Michael Rossetti]], one of the seven founding members of the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] and the editor of its literary magazine ''[[The Germ (periodical)|The Germ]]''. A granddaughter of [[Gabriele Rossetti]] and [[Ford Madox Brown]], she was hence a niece of [[Maria Francesca Rossetti]], [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] and [[Christina Rossetti]], as well as a first cousin of [[Ford Madox Ford]].
While still in their girlhood, Olivia and her sister, the future Helen Rossetti Angeli (1879-1969), began publishing an anarchist journal, ''The Torch'', in the basement of their family home. Despite their youth, this effort became the nucleus of a prominent anarchist salon which included [[Peter Kropotkin]] and [[Sergei Kravchinski]], and their publishing coups included the pamphlet ''Why I Am an Anarchist'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]]. Years later, using the pseudonym "Isabel Meredith", Olivia and Helen published ''A Girl Among the Anarchists'', a somewhat fictionalized memoir of their days as precocious child revolutionaries. These adventures were also chronicled by their cousin Ford Madox Ford in his 1931 memoir ''Return to Yesterday''.<ref>Olivia Rossetti Agresti Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library Finding Aid. "[http://hdl.handle.net/10079/fa/beinecke.agresti]"</ref>
A more permanent consequence of this political activity was Olivia's marriage in 1897 to the Italian anarchist and journalist Antonio Agresti (1866-1926), which led to her emigration from England to Italy. Olivia was to remain there for the rest of her life and she eventually became an Italian citizen. During her first years in Italy she continued with literary activities related to her political activism, including a biography of the Italian painter and revolutionary [[Giovanni Costa]].
== Internationalism ==
The second phase in Agresti's career began in 1904, when she met the American agricultural reformer [[David Lubin]]. A former department store and mail order magnate from [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], Lubin was in Rome seeking a state sponsor for his idea of an international clearinghouse for agricultural statistics. Unable to speak Italian, Lubin hired Agresti as his interpreter and thus began a close collaboration between the two which continued until Lubin's death.
With Agresti's assistance, Lubin's efforts in Italy made history. After gaining the unexpected support of Italy's king [[Victor Emmanuel III of Italy|Victor Emmanuel III]], Lubin's vision became a reality with the 1905 founding of the [[International Institute of Agriculture]], headquartered in Rome. The first modern international organization, it was hailed as a significant forerunner of [[world government]] by such luminaries as [[H. G. Wells]] and [[Louis Brandeis]]. Agresti includes samples of Lubin's correspondence with Wells and Brandeis in her 1922 biography ''David Lubin: A Study in Practical Idealism''.
Following Lubin's death in 1919, Agresti waged a public campaign for close cooperation between the International Institute of Agriculture and the nascent [[League of Nations]], which soon employed her as a member of the staff to Italy's delegation. She continued as a staff interpreter for the League in Geneva from 1922 to 1930. Her last assignment as a professional interpreter occurred in 1945 when, at the personal request of Italy's prime minister, [[Alcide De Gasperi]], she accompanied him to London for meetings of the [[Council of Foreign Ministers]]. According to her unpublished memoirs, meetings at which Agresti interpreted included [[Ernest Bevin]] and [[Vyacheslav Molotov]].
== Fascism ==
By 1921 Agresti's early anarchist leanings, further leavened by years of exposure to Lubin's theories concerning [[cooperative]] organization of society, had transformed her into an enthusiastic supporter of [[corporatism]] and, consequently, of [[Benito Mussolini]]'s corporatist reorganization of the Italian economy. From 1921 to 1943 she edited the newsletter of the ''Associazione fra le Società per Azioni'', a group then closely allied with the Fascists, and in 1938 co-authored the theoretical work ''The Organization of the Arts and Professions in the Fascist Guild State'' with the Fascist journalist [[:It:Mario Missiroli|Mario Missiroli]].
In 1937, Agresti's editorship of economic journals brought her into professional contact with [[Ezra Pound]], then residing in Italy and writing articles in Italian on economic topics. Thus began a long correspondence between the two which lasted until 1959, the year before Agresti's death. Agresti seems to have been unaware of Pound's fame as a poet, and Pound unaware of Agresti's family ties to [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] and [[Ford Madox Ford]], two of the most important influences on his poetry, until years into the correspondence. Portions of this correspondence were edited and published in 1998 by the [[University of Illinois Press]].
Agresti became practically a member of Pound's extended family as the years progressed, and she and her two adopted Italian daughters were frequent guests at [[Schloss Brunnenburg]]. She was active for years in the international campaign to free Pound from his involuntary incarceration in a mental asylum by the government of the United States, and Pound in turn tried to assist her, then suffering from an impecunious old age, by finding a publisher for her memoirs. Pound refers to Agresti twice in his ''[[The Cantos|Cantos]]''.
== Selected works == *1903. ''A Girl Among the Anarchists'' (co-authored with her sister Helen under the pseudonym "Isabel Meredith"). London: Duckworth Press.[https://archive.org/details/agirlamonganarc00meregoog edition Internet Archive] *1904. ''Giovanni Costa: His Life, Work, and Times''. London: Grant Richards. *1920. "LEAGUE OF AGRICULTURE; How Institute David Lubin Founded Will Supplement Greater League of Nations", ''New York Times'', 23 May, Page XX16 *1922. ''David Lubin: A Study in Practical Idealism''. Babcock Brady-Handy Cropped Portrait.jpg |image_size= 220 |caption= Orville E. Babcock |allegiance= [[United States of America]]
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch= [[United States Army]]
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears=1861–1884 |rank= [[File:Union Army colonel rank insignia.png|border|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]]
[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|border|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands= |unit=[[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] |battles=[[American Civil War]]: {{plainlist|indent=0.5| *[[Battle of Fredericksburg]] *[[Peninsular Campaign]] *[[Siege of Yorktown (1862)|Siege of Yorktown]] *[[Siege of Vicksburg]] *[[Battle of Blue Springs]] *[[Knoxville Campaign]] *[[Battle of Fort Sanders]] *[[Overland Campaign]] }} |awards= |laterwork=[[Secretary to the President of the United States|Private Secretary]] for President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] (1869–1877) }} '''Orville Elias Babcock''' (December 25, 1835 – June 2, 1884) was an engineer, and [[American Civil War]] [[General officer|general]] in the [[Union Army]]. An aide to General [[Ulysses S. Grant]] during and after the war, he was [[President of the United States|President]] Grant's private secretary at the White House, Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds for [[Washington D.C.]], and a Florida-based federal inspector of lighthouses. Babcock continued to serve as lighthouse inspector under Grant's successors [[Rutherford B. Hayes]], [[James A. Garfield]], and [[Chester A Arthur]]. A native of Vermont, Babcock graduated third in his class at [[United States Military Academy at West Point|West Point]] in 1861, and served in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] throughout the Civil War. As Assistant Engineer and [[aide-de-camp]] for district commander [[Nathaniel P. Banks]], in 1862 Babcock worked on fortifications to aid in defending the nation's capitol from Confederate attack. Babcock later served as [[aide-de-camp]] for Ulysses S. Grant and participated in the [[Overland Campaign]]. He was promoted to [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[brigadier general]] in 1865 and continued on Grant's staff during [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]]. In 1867, Babcock warned Grant of a white supremacist insurgency that used Confederate symbolism to intimidate blacks in the South. After Grant became President in 1869, Babcock was assigned Grant's [[Secretary to the President of the United States]]—in modern terms, the chief of staff—and he served until his departure from the White House in 1876. Babcock's salary was paid by the U.S. Army and he was not subject to Congressional approval. Grant also appointed Babcock Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds for Washington, DC. Babcock, at the time, was young and ambitious, and considered the [[Iago]] of the Grant administration. In 1869, Grant sent Babcock on a mission to explore the possibility of annexing the island nation of [[Dominican Republic|Santo Domingo]] to the United States, but the Senate led by [[Charles Sumner]] rejected the proposal. Babcock's tenure under President Grant was embroiled in corruption charges, and his manipulation of both cabinet departments and appointments. Grant supported Babcock when Babcock was accused of corruption; Grant's shielding of Babcock from political attack stemmed primarily from their shared experiences on the battlefield during the [[American Civil War]]. When Babcock was indicted as a member of the [[Whiskey Ring]] in 1875, Grant believed it was an indictment on his presidency. He provided a written deposition on Babcock's behalf—a first for a sitting president—which was admitted at Babcock's 1876 trial and resulted in his acquittal. The news coverage of the Whiskey Ring and other Grant administration scandals caused public opinion to turn against Babcock. Upon his return from St. Louis, Babcock was reluctant to leave his post, as if nothing happened, but under pressure from Secretary Fish, Grant forced Babcock to leave the White House. President Grant would not desert his wartime comrade; in February 1877, he appointed Babcock Inspector of Lighthouses for the Federal Lighthouse Board's Fifth District, a low-profile post that did not attract undue public attention. In 1882, President [[Chester A. Arthur]] additionally appointed Babcock Inspector of Lighthouses for the Federal Lighthouse Board's Sixth District. Babcock was the chief engineer overseeing plans for the construction of [[Ponce de Leon Inlet Light|Mosquito Inlet Lighthouse]]. He died in 1884 on duty when he drowned off Mosquito Inlet in [[Daytona Beach, Florida]]. Babcock's historical reputation is mixed; his technical engineering expertise, efficiency, bravery in battle, and [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] loyalty were offset by his involvement in corruption, deception, and scandal. Uncommon for his times, Babcock showed no racism in relations with [[African Americans]] or mixed race peoples, which was a key factor in Grant's decision to send Babcock to Santo Domingo, whose population was predominantly mixed race, and consisted of individuals with [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indian]], [[Demographics of Africa|African]], and [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic]] ancestry. ==Early life == Orville E. Babcock was born on December 25, 1835 in [[Franklin, Vermont|Franklin]], [[Vermont]], a small town located near the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–US border]] close to [[Lake Champlain]]. Babcock's father was Elias Babcock Jr. and his mother was Clara Olmsted.Dictionary of American Biography (1928), ''Babcock, Orville E.'', p. 460 While growing up in Vermont he received a common education.New York Times (June 4, 1884) , ''Gen. Babcock Drowned'' At the age of 16, Babcock was appointed to the [[United States Military Academy|West Point Military Academy]] (USMA), where he graduated third in a class of 45 on May 6, 1861. His high class ranking enabled Babcock to select his branch, and he chose the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Engineers]], as did most top graduates of his era.{{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Evan C. |last2=Sword |first2=Wiley |date=2014 |title=Gateway to the Confederacy: New Perspectives on the Chickamauga and Chattanooga Campaigns, 1862-1863 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VwM6AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA116 |location=Chapel Hill, NC |publisher=University of North Carolina Press |page=116 |isbn=978-0-8071-5512-7}}{{cite book |last=Babcock |first=Stephen |date=1903 |title=Isaiah Babcock, Sr. and his descendants |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dtcUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA776 |location=New York, NY |publisher=Eaton & Mains |page=776}} ==Civil War (1861–1865) == ===Constructed Washington D.C. defense works=== The [[American Civil War]] was beginning as Babcock was graduating; he was commissioned as a [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Second Lieutenant]] in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Corps of Engineers]], and assigned to duty as an Assistant Engineer for the military district that included Washington. His first mission was the undertaking of efforts to improve the defensive works of Washington, D.C. and protect the city from attack. On July 13, 1861, Babcock was assigned to the Department of Pennsylvania. In August, he received his commission as a second lieutenant, to date from his West Point graduation in May; he was assigned to the Department of the Shenandoah, and constructed military fortifications on the [[Potomac River]] and in the [[Shenandoah Valley]] while also serving as [[aide-de-camp]] under Major General [[Nathaniel P. Banks]]. From August through November, Babcock worked again on improving the fortifications surrounding Washington, responding to increased apprehension the Union capital was vulnerable to attack and capture by the [[Confederate Army]]. ===Peninsular campaign=== [[image:O.E. Babcock and O.M. Poe Battle of Ft. Sanders.jpg|thumb|175px |right |Orville E. Babcock (left)
and Orlando M. Poe (right),
Union Engineers in Ft. Sander's salient. Photograph by Barnard, 1863–1864.]] On November 17, 1861, Babcock was promoted to [[First Lieutenant#United States|First Lieutenant]], Corps of Engineers, and a week later was assigned to the [[Army of the Potomac]]. During the months of February and March, 1862, while General Banks moved to Winchester, Virginia, Babcock set up military fortifications at [[Harpers Ferry, West Virginia|Harper's Ferry]] and guarded [[pontoon bridge|pontoon]] bridges crossing the Potomac River. During the [[Peninsular Campaign]], Babcock served bravely at the [[Siege of Yorktown (1862)|Siege of Yorktown]] with the Army of the Potomac's Engineer Battalion and was breveted as a captain to rank from May 4, 1862. For the next seven months, Babcock built bridges, roads, and field works. For his service, in November, 1862, Babcock was promoted to Chief Engineer Left Grand Division of the Army of the Potomac. In December 1862, during the [[Battle of Fredericksburg]], Babcock served on Brigadier General [[William B. Franklin]]'s engineering staff. ===Vicksburg, Blue Springs, Campbell's Station=== On January 1, 1863, Babcock was promoted to permanent captain and brevet [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]], and was named the Assistant Inspector General of the [[VI Corps (ACW)|VI Corps]] until February 6, when he was named the Assistant Inspector General and Chief Engineer of the [[IX Corps (ACW)|IX Corps]]. As Chief Engineer of the IX Corps, Babcock surveyed and projected the defensive fortifications at [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]] and Central Kentucky. Moving westward to help secure the Mississippi River from Confederate control and divide the Confederacy in two, Babcock fought with the IX Corps at the [[Battle of Vicksburg]] and the [[Battle of Blue Springs]], and the [[Battle of Campbell's Station]]. ===Knoxville campaign=== [[file:Kurz & Allison - Assault on Fort Sanders.jpg|thumb|left|220px|
'''Battle of Fort Sanders'''
]] Babcock was part of [[XXIII Corps (Union Army)|XXIII Corps]], and served under Union engineer Captain [[Orlando M. Poe]]. Poe and Union engineers, that included Babcock, built several fortifications in the form of bastioned earthworks near Knoxville. One was Fort Sanders, just west of downtown Knoxville across a creek valley. It was named for [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brig. Gen.]] [[William P. Sanders]], mortally wounded in a skirmish outside Knoxville on November 18, 1863.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} The fort, had an innovative design, and was a salient in the line of earthworks that surrounded three sides of the city, rose {{convert|70|ft|m}} above the surrounding plateau and was protected by a ditch {{convert|12|ft|m}} wide and {{convert|8|ft|m}} deep.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} An almost insurmountable vertical wall rose {{convert|15|ft|m}} above the ditch, slippery and frozen.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} Inside the fort were 12 cannons and 440 men of the 79th New York Infantry. In front of the ditch, telegraph wires were strung at knee height across tree stumps, possibly the first use of such wire entanglements in the Civil War, to entangle Confederate soldiers that would assault the Fort.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} The Battle of Fort Sanders was brutal by 19th Century standards.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} The Confederates moved to within 120-150 yards of the salient during the night of freezing rain and snow and waited for the order to attack.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} Entangled by the telegraph wire, Confederate soldiers were shot by Union soldiers atop the wall.{{sfn|''The Longest Night''|pages=615-616}} After crossing the ditch, the Confederates were unable to dig footholds, men climbed upon each other's shoulders to attempt to reach the top of the wall. Union soldiers rained fire into the assault, including musketry, canister, and artillery shells thrown as hand grenades. A succession of color bearers was shot down as they planted their flags on the fort. For a brief time, three flags reached the top, those of the 16th Georgia, 13th Mississippi, and 17th Mississippi. After 40 minutes of battle, the Confederates broke and retreated. The battle ended in a lopsided Union victory. After fighting in the [[Knoxville Campaign]], at the [[Battle of Fort Sanders]], Babcock became the Chief Engineer of the [[Department of the Ohio]] and was promoted to brevet major on November 29, 1863. ===Overland Campaign=== [[Image:UlyssesSGrant staff ca1865 byJAWhipple Harvard.png|thumb|right|275px |Lieut. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Staff: [[Ulysses S. Grant]] (at center table), Orville E. Babcock (right)]] Babcock was promoted to lieutenant colonel in the regular army on March 29, 1864 and became the aide-de-camp to Lieutenant General [[Ulysses S. Grant]] participating in [[Overland Campaign]] against General [[Robert E. Lee]] and the Confederate [[Army of Northern Virginia]].{{sfn|White|2016|p=xvii}} Babcock served in the [[Battle of the Wilderness]], the [[Battle of Spotsylvania Court House]], and the [[Battle of Cold Harbor]]. For his gallant service at the Battle of the Wilderness, Babcock was appointed [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]], U.S. Volunteers, to rank from May 6, 1864.{{cite book| author = | last = Eicher | first = John H. | author2 = | last2 = Eicher | first2 = David J. | authorlink2 = David J. Eicher | publication-date= 2001 |title= Civil War High Commands | page = 111 | publisher = Stanford University Press | location = Stanford, CA | ISBN = 978-0-8047-3641-1 }} On August 9, 1864, Babcock, while stationed at Union headquarters in [[City Point, Virginia|City Point]], was wounded in the hand after Confederate spies had blown up an ammunition barge moored below the city's bluffs.Catton (1969), p. 349. As Grant's aide-de-camp, Babcock ran dispatches between Grant and Major General [[William T. Sherman]] during [[Sherman's March to the Sea]] campaign. ===Appomattox: Lee surrenders to Grant=== [[image:Lee Surrenders to Grant at Appomattox.jpg |180px|right|thumb|Robert E. Lee surrender to Ulysses S. Grant at the McLean House on April 9, 1865]] On April 9, 1865 after being defeated at the [[Appomattox Campaign|Battle of Appomattox]], Commanding Confederate General [[Robert E. Lee]] formally surrendered his Army of Northern Virginia to [[Ulysses S. Grant]]. Babcock personally chose the site of surrender at the McLean House, personally escorted Lee to the meeting, and witnessed Grant and Lee discussing and signing the surrender terms. For his meritorious contributions in the Civil War, Babcock was appointed brevet colonel, to rank from March 13, 1865. On July 17, 1866, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] nominated Babcock for brevet brigadier general in the regular army, to rank from March 13, 1865, and the [[United States Senate]] confirmed the appointment on July 23, 1866.Eicher, 2001, p. 732. ==Reconstruction== {{further |Reconstruction Era|Presidency of Ulysses S. Grant}} ===Final promotions, marriage, and family=== [[image:NORTH (MAIN) ELEVATION, VIEW EAST ON G STREET. - Orville E. Babcock House, Washington, District of Columbia, DC HABS DC,WASH,396-3.tif|thumb|180px|right|Orville E. Babcock's house in Washington D.C.]] After the War, Babcock remained on Grant's staff throughout America's turbulent [[Reconstruction Era of the United States|Reconstruction Period]]. On July 25, 1866, Brig. Gen. Babcock was commissioned Colonel of Staff and aide-de-camp for General-in-Chief of the Army, Ulysses S. Grant.{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} On March 21, 1867 Babcock received a Regular Army commission as a major in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Corps of Engineers]].{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} On November 6, 1866, Babcock married Anne Eliza Cambell in [[Galena, Illinois]].{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=132}} Their marriage produced four children: Campbell E. Babcock, Orville E. Babcock, Jr., Adolph B. Babcock, and Benjamin Babcock. Benjamin died during infancy.[http://www.newberry.org/collections/FindingAids/babcock/Babcock.html Inventory of the Orville E. Babcock Papers] (2008) Babcock moved to Washington D.C. to serve under Grant while Grant was Commanding General and President of the United States. ===Reported on South (1867)=== In mid-April Commanding General Grant dispatched Babcock and [[Horace Porter]], another member of Grant's staff, to report on the progress of Southern Reconstruction.{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=588}} Babcock and Porter were optimistic on the plight of blacks who had embraced citizenship saying the "negro is learning very fast. They will soon be the best educated ''class'' in the South, if they continue at their present rate of progress."{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=588}} However, Babcock discovered and informed Grant of a white supremacist insurgency and Confederate symbolism were developing that intimidated [[African Americans]], saying that in Georgia the "police in most of the cities are in a grey uniform, the real ''confederate'' uniform."{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=588}} ===President Grant's military secretary (1869–1876)=== In 1868, Ulysses S. Grant was elected the 18th President of the United States. In 1869, General Babcock was assigned Grant's military [[Secretary to the President (US)|private secretary]].{{cite book | last = Reeves | first = Thomas C. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Gentleman Boss | publisher = Alfred A. Knopf | year = 1975 | location = NY, NY | page = 59 | isbn = 0-394-46095-2}} Babcock worked directly for President Grant. Babcock, one of a few men who had daily access to President Grant at the White House, had unprecedented influence over President Grant and planted suspicions in Grant that enemies were out to politically destroy his administration. His influence even extended indirectly into many cabinet departments and he was at odds with reformers, that included Secretary Fish and Secretary Bristow, who both had desired to save Grant's reputation from scandal. When cabinet appointments came available, Grant listened to Babcock's recommendations.Woodward (1957), ''The Lowest Ebb'' Babcock, who was admired by Grant for his [[American Civil War|Civil War]] service, was young and ambitious and considered the [[Iago]] of the Grant administration.{{sfn|Simon 2002|p=249}} ====Gatekeeper to Grant==== Babcock was 33 years old at the time of Grant's inauguration.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=78}} He retained his position in the U.S. Army under Sherman, who under special arrangement with Grant was allowed to be the President's personal secretary.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=77}} Babcock did not require Senate confirmation for his appointment, while he retained his military salary.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=77}} Babcock's duties included involvement in patronage matters, finding dirt on Grant's administration critics, and feeding political stories to pro-Grant newspapers.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=78}} Babcock's office was in an anteroom on the second floor of the White House that led to President Grant's private office.{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} In order to see Grant, visitors had to go through Babcock,{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} a circumstance that caused many to resent Babcock's insider role, and created a negative perception among contemporaries that overrode Babcock's positive attributes.{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} Babcock also opened and answered most of Grant's personal letters,{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} and historian [[Allan Nevins]] argued that Babcock's position was as at least as important as the Cabinet secretaries, and more powerful than most.{{sfn|Kirshner 1999|p=133}} ====Santo Domingo annextation (1869-1871)==== {{see|Annexation of Santo Domingo}} [[image:Santo Domingo City Taylor 1871.tif|thumb|left|220px|
Santo Domingo City '''''1871'''''
]] After his appointment, in 1869, Babcock was involved as a special agent of President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] in the attempt to annex the mostly black [[Caribbean]] island country of the [[Dominican Republic]] (''18,655 mi²''), then commonly called ''Santo Domingo''.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} At this time, federal land speculation was not uncommon, as Congress had in March 1867, [[Alaska Purchase|purchased Alaska]] (''663,300 mi²'') from the [[Russian Empire]].{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=661}} Like his predecessor, [[Andrew Johnson]], Grant received inducements for Caribbean expansion particularly for [[Haiti]] and the Dominican Republic.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=163}} Speculators William L. Cazneau and Joseph W. Fabens formed the ''Santo Domingo Company'' in New York to gain investment backers for the annexation of the Dominican Republic.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=163}} Grant's Secretary of State [[Hamilton Fish]], was doubtful concerning Haitian annexation, believing the country to unstable, but he was initially more favorable to annexing the Dominican Republic after realizing investors were highly enthusiastic towards investing in the country.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=163}} Fish, however, became suspicious of annexation when Fabens, representing promoters, approached Fish and asked him to support a plan of American annexation of the Dominican Republic.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} Grant, who was more favorable to wealthy business leaders and investors, supported annexation.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} Fish, supporting Grant out of loyalty, agreed to send Babcock on a reconnaissance mission, Grant's appointed special agent to the Dominican Republic.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|pp=164-165}} Babcock was accompanied by Fabens and annexation supporter California Republican Senator [[Cornelius Cole]].{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} Cazneau, who was on the island, formerly introduced the young and ambitious Babcock to the Dominican Republic President [[Buenaventura Báez]], and the two unknown to Fish, made a draft of annexation.{{sfnm|Pletcher|1998|1p=164|White|2016|2p=508}} According to the annexation draft made in September 1869, Samaná Bay would be sold to the United States for $2 million or the country would be annexed to the United States after paying of the Dominican Republic's national debt of $1.5 million.{{sfnm|Pletcher|1998|1p=164|White|2016|2p=508}} Babcock was a supporter of Congressional [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]], and he saw Santo Domingo, not as a nation of blacks, but as a source of new opportunities in a post war world.{{sfn|McFeely|1981|p=340}} [[image:Jacob Dolson Cox Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Grant's Secretary of Interior Cox dared to question Santo Domingo annexation]] When Babcock returned to the White House having a treaty, Fish and Secretary of Interior [[Jacob D. Cox]] were alarmed, since Babcock had no official standing.{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=453}} Fish told Cox, "Babcock is back...I pledge you my word he had no more diplomatic authority than any other casual visitor to the island."{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=453}}{{sfnm|Pletcher|1998|1p=164|White|2p=508}} At the next cabinet meeting Babcock was there in person and Grant told his silenced cabinet that Babcock was back and that he approved of the treaty, while it only needed a signature from the U.S. consular in Santo Domingo.{{sfn|Brands|2012|pp=453-454}} Cox spoke up and said, " But Mr. President, has it been settled, then, that we ''want'' to annex Santo Domingo ?" Grant was embarrassed and began puffing on his cigar, while the other cabinet members said nothing, Cox's question remained unanswered.{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=454}} Fish threatened to resign over the matter, but Grant convinced him to stay on the administration telling Fish he would not go around him again and he needed Fish's guidance and support.{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=454}} Fish agreed to remain on the cabinet, although he hoped Grant would drop the Santo Domingo annexation treaty.{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=454}} Grant, however, did not drop the treaty, having believed annexation would help alleviate violent suppression of [[African Americans]] in the Southern states, as blacks would have a safe environment to work and live, in the Dominican Republic. Fish sent Babcock back to the Dominican Republic on November 18, accompanied by Quartermaster [[Rufus Ingalls]], this time having official State Department status and instructions to draw up two formal treaties, signed on November 29, 1869.{{sfnm|Pletcher|1998|1p=164|White|2016|2p=509}} Grant, however, kept the treaties secret from Congress and the public, until mid-January 1870.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} After earnest public discussion, the treaties was formerly submitted to Congress in March, whereupon Senators joined in the debate.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|p=164}} Senator [[Charles Sumner]] strongly opposed the annexation treaties objecting to Babcock's secret negotiations, his use of naval power, and desiring to keep Santo Domingo an autonomous [[African American]] nation rather than annexation and potential statehood as Grant had proposed. The people of Santo Domingo overwhelmingly desired annexation voting 15,169 to 11 in its favor, according to a plebiscite held by Báez.{{sfn|Pletcher|1998|pp=164-165}} Senate Republicans led by Sumner split the party over the treaty while Senators loyal to Grant supported the treaty and admonished Babcock. The treaties however failed to pass the Senate causing continued bitterness and hostility between Grant and Sumner, both stubbornly trying to control the Republican Party. Although Babcock was suspected of being given investment land on Samaná Bay, a Congressional investigation found no conclusive evidence that Babcock would financially gain from the country's annexation.{{sfnm|McFeely|1974|1p=138|McFeely|1981|2p=343}} Babcock in the minority report was criticized for acquiescing in the imprisonment of Davis Hatch, an American abroad, who was an open critic of Báez.{{sfn|McFeely|1974|p=138}} ====Gold corner (September 1869)==== In 1869, Babcock invested money in the [[Jay Cooke & Company]]'s [[Black Friday (1869)|Gold Ring]], a scam by wealthy New York [[tycoons]] [[Jay Gould]] and [[James Fisk (financier)|James Fisk]] to profit by [[cornering the market]] on gold.{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=647}} Starting in late April, Secretary of the Treasury [[George S. Boutwell]] had regulated the price of gold by monthly sales from the Treasury in exchange for [[United States Note#Post Civil War|greenbacks]].{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=128}} As part of the Gold Ring's effort, Gould convinced Grant not to increase the Treasury's September gold sale, helping make it scarce and inflating the price.{{sfnm|Chernow|2017|1p=647|Calhoun|2017|2p=134}} Gould and Fisk then set up a buying operation, the New York Gold Room, where traders in their employ purchased as much gold as they could acquire, which artificially drove up the price.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|pp=140-141}} When Grant became aware of the full extent of the attempt to corner the market in late September 1869, he ordered the release of $4,500,000 in Treasury gold, which caused the price to collapse.{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=647}} Gould and Fisk were thwarted, but at the expense of a decline in the stock market and the overall economy.{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=647}} Babcock and other individuals who secretly invested with him lost $40,000 (about $750,000 in 2018).{{sfn|Chernow|2017|p=647}}, and to satisfy his creditors, Babcock had to sign a [[Deed of trust (real estate)|trust deed]] on his property, which named [[Asa Bird Gardiner]] as trustee.{{sfn|Knott|1876|p=421}} The extent of Babcock's involvement was not revealed to Grant until 1876, when his complicity in the Gold Ring was uncovered during the investigation of his involvement in the Whiskey Ring.Simon ''The Papers of Ulysses S. Grant: January 1-October 31, 1876'' , pages 47, 48 ====Corruption: Whiskey Ring (1875–1876)==== {{further |Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration scandals}} [[image:Whiskeyring.jpg|thumb |200px |left |[[Thomas Nast]] cartoon depicting the [[Whiskey Ring]], published in ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' (March, 1876)]] Dating back to the Presidency of [[Abraham Lincoln]] it was common for distillers and corrupt Internal Revenue agents to make false whiskey production reports and pocket unpaid tax revenue.{{sfn|McFeely|1974|p=154}} However, during the early 1870s, the corruption became more organized by distillers, who used the illegally obtained money for bribery and illegal election financing, to the point where every agent in St. Louis was involved in corruption.{{sfn|McFeely|1974|p=154}} This organized network, known as the [[Whiskey Ring]], extended nationally and involved "the printing, selling, and approving of forged federal revenue stamps on bottled whiskey."Fredman (1987), ''The Presidential Follies'' In June 1874, President Grant appointed [[Benjamin Bristow]] as Secretary of Treasury, with authority to investigate the Whiskey Ring and prosecute wrongdoers. Bristow, a Kentuckian and Union Army veteran, was known for his honesty and integrity, and had served as the nation's first Solicitor General, also appointed by Grant.{{sfn|White|2016|p=556}} Bristow immediately discovered whiskey tax evasion among distillers and corrupt officials in the Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Bureau.{{sfn|White|2016|p=557}} Bristow and [[Bluford Wilson]], the [[Solicitor of the United States Treasury|Treasury Solicitor]] obtained Grant's permission to use secret agents appointed from outside the Treasury Department; as a result of the evidence they obtained, on May 10, 1875 Treasury Department agents raided and shut down corrupt distilleries in St. Louis, Chicago, and Milwaukee, seizing company financial records and other files.{{sfn|White|2016|p=557}} Bristow then prosecuted the offenders by working with Grant's newly appointed Attorney General, [[Edwards Pierrepont]], a popular New York reformer who had been involved in shutting down New York City's corrupt [[William M. Tweed|Tweed Ring]].{{sfn|White|2016|p=557}} Information was soon discovered that Babcock was informing ring leader John McDonald in St. Louis of inspections by Bristow's agents, giving them time to hide incriminating evidence before agents arrived.{{sfn|White|2016|p=562}} Bristow believed Babcock was paid off by cash, two five-hundred-dollar bills, in one instance, hidden a inside cigar box, for this information and protection.{{sfn|White|2016|p=562}} McDonald was indicted in June, when Bristow obtained indictments against 350 distillers and government officials.{{sfn|White|2016|p=562}} {{multiple image | direction=horizontal | width1=131 | image1=Benjamin Helm Bristow Brady - Handy U.S. Secretary of Treasury.jpg | alt1=Photo of Secertary of Treasury Benjamin Bristow | caption1=
[[Benjamin Bristow]]
| width2=128 | image2=Edwards Pierrepont Brady-Handy.tif | alt2=Photo of Attorney General Edwards Pierrepont | caption2=
[[Edwards Pierrepont]]
| align=right | header=
Grant's anti-corruption team, Bristow and Pierrepont, confronted Babcock over the Whiskey Ring, at the White House.
}} In July 1875, Bristow and Pierrepont met Grant, who was vacationing at Long Branch, and gave him evidence that Babcock was a member of the ring. {{sfnm|White|2016|1p=562|McFeely|1974|2p=156}} Grant told Pierrepont "Let no guilty man escape..." and said if Babcock was guilty then it was the "greatest piece of traitorism to me that a man could possibly practice."{{sfn|White|2016|p=562}} In October, Babcock was summoned in front of Grant, Bristow, and Pierrepont at the White House to explain two ambiguously signed "Sylph" telegrams hand written by Babcock.{{sfnm|White|2016|1p=563|Brands|2012|2p=557|McFeely|1981|3p=410}} The first message said, "''I have succeeded. They will not go. I will write you.''" (December 10, 1874) and the second one said, "''We have official information that the enemy weakens. Push things.''" (February 3, 1875){{sfn|Smith|2001|p=591}} Bristow had shown these messages to Grant at a cabinet meeting the same day.{{sfn|White|2016|p=563}} Babcock said something to Grant, unintelligible to Bristow and Pierrepont, and Grant appeared satisfied by Babcock's interpretation of the telegrams.{{sfnm|White|2016|1p=563|McFeely|1981|2p=410}} Pierrepont and Bristow, believing the matter to be crucial, insisted Babcock send a message to his telegraphic correspondent demanding that this individual come to Washington to give his version of the messages.{{sfnm|Brands|2012|1p=557|McFeely|1981|2p=411}} After Babcock seemed to be taking too long, Pierrepont went to check on him and found Babcock writing a warning to revenue agent John A. Joyce, his St. Louis confederate, to be on his guard.{{sfn|McFeely|1981|p=411}} Infuriated, Pierrepont grabbed Babcock's pen and dashed through his message yelling "You don't want to send your argument; send the fact, and go there and make your explanation. ''I'' don't understand this."{{sfnm|Brands|2012|1p=557|McFeely|1981|2p=411}} Grant, on the other hand, was divided between the loyalty he had for Babcock, and his desire for Bristow and Pierrepont, trustworthy members of his cabinet, to prosecute the Whiskey Ring.{{sfn|White|2016|p=562}} Since Babcock had no acceptable explanation for his messages, he was soon indicted November 4, 1875 for tax fraud.{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=557}} As a military officer, on December 2, 1875 Babcock requested of Grant a military court martial, believing that an army tribunal would be favorable to his defense.{{sfn|McFeely|1974|p=157}} On December 8, 1875, U.S. Attorney [[David Patterson Dyer|David Dyer]] followed Bristow's instructions to deny Babcock a court martial, setting his St. Louis jury trial for February, 1876.{{sfn|White|2016|p=563}} When Babcock's trial in St. Louis came up in February, Grant decided to testify in Babcock's defense.{{sfn|White|2016|p=564}} By this time, Grant said his critics were using Babcock to go after his own presidency.{{sfn|White|2016|p=563}} After cabinet members objected to Grant testifying in St. Louis as unseemly for a President, it was settled that Grant would give a deposition at the White House.{{sfn|White|2016|p=564}} =====St. Louis Trial (February 1876)===== [[file:William Tecumseh Sherman.jpg|thumb|right|150px|General '''William T. Sherman''' testified at Babcock's trial.]] On February 8, 1876 Babcock was put on trial, an event that lasted eighteen days.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} Babcock's defense team was noted for its legal prowess, and included Grant's former Attorney General [[George Henry Williams|George Williams]], a top criminal defense lawyer, Emory Storrs, and a former appeals judge (New York), [[John K. Porter]].{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=522}} It took place at the U.S. Post Office and Custom House located at 218 North Third Street, and the status of the defendant made the trial a popular and well-attended spectacle.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} Demand to attend the courtroom proceedings was so great that only persons with signed passes and Whiskey Ring defendants were allowed in.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} Babcock arrived in civilian clothes, including sky-blue pants, a silk hat, and a light jacket.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} When court wasn't in session, Babcock stayed at the newly rebuilt [[Lindell Hotel]] on Sixth Street and Washington Avenue.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} Grant's White House deposition took place on February 12; it was notarized by Chief Justice [[Morrison Waite]] and witnessed by both Bristow and Pierrepont.{{sfn|White|2016|p=564}} At the deposition Grant fully supported the Whiskey Ring prosecutions, but he willfully refused to testify against Babcock, despite having been informed by Bristow of Babcock's duplicity, saying he had "great confidence" in Babcock's integrity, and that his confidence in Babcock was "unshaken".{{sfnm|White|2016|1p=564|Chernow|2010|2p=806}} Grant's unprecedented testimony would prove to be devastating to for the Whiskey Ring prosecution team against Babcock. On February 17, Babcock's defense read President Grant's powerful deposition that supported Babcock to the jury, and severely weakened any chance of Babcock being convicted.{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} The same day, General [[William T. Sherman]], testified at the trial, that Babcock's "character has been very good."{{sfn|O'neil|2017}} Grant's deposition, Sherman's in-person tesitmony, and Babcock's shrewed defense counsel led to his acquittal by the St. Louis jury.{{sfn|White|2016|p=564}} A rumor spread that Pierrepont had leaked information to Babcock that aided in his acquittal, but Pierrepont denied this and suggested that Babcock himself had started the rumor.{{cite book | last = Reeves | first = Thomas C. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Gentleman Boss | publisher = Alfred A. Knopf | year = 1975 | location = NY, NY | pages = 80–81 | isbn = 0-394-46095-2}} A few months later Grant's appointed anti-corruption team broke up. Pierrepont resigned office on May 21, 1876 and was appointed by Grant [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|United States Minister to the United Kingdom]] on July 11, 1876.{{cite book |last=Hannan |first=Caryn |date=2008 |title=Connecticut Biographical Dictionary |url=https://books.google.de/books?id=Pd_ETIlgTxgC&pg=PA437 |location=Hamburg, MI |publisher=State History Publications |pages=437-438 |isbn=978-1-878592-72-9}} Enmity between Grant and Bristow forced Bristow out of the cabinet, and he resigned on June 20, 1876.{{cite book |last1=Colton |first1=David Douty |last2=Huntington |first2=Collis Potter |date=1992 |title=The Octopus Speaks: The Colton Letters |url=https://books.google.de/books?id=DjdPAQAAIAAJ&dq=bristow+resign+treasury+enmity&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22In+this+position+he+spear-headed+the+Whiskey+Fraud+investigations+which+gained+him+the+undying+enmity+of+Grant.%22 |location=San Luis Rey, CA |publisher=Tentacled Press |page=155}} ====Return to Washington D.C.==== When Babcock returned to Washington, he went back to his White House office, as if there had been no trial. Grant's Secretary of State, [[Hamilton Fish]], was furious, and pressured Grant to force Babcock to leave, saying that Grant merely had to dismiss Babcock, because as a military officer Babcock was subject to orders and had no recourse. Additionally Treasury Solicitor Wilson informed Grant that Babcock had been involved with the 1869 plot to [[Black Friday (1869)|corner the gold market]].{{sfn|Brands|2012|p=560}} Grant finally dismissed Babcock from the White House and appointed his son Ulysses Jr. in Babcock's place.{{sfn|White|2016|p=564}} It was later discovered that Babcock used his Whiskey Ring kickbacks to purchase from [[Henry Shelton Sanford]] on Christmas Day, 1874 a home and over 50 acres of grove land near what became the city of [[Sanford, Florida]].Robison (Jan 6, 2002), ''[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2002-01-06/news/0201040436_1_babcock-whiskey-ring-sanford Deeds, Letter Prove General's Ties to Sanford]'', Accessed on February 9, 2017 ===Superintendent of public buildings and grounds (1869–1877)=== In addition to being Grant's private secretary Grant had appointed Babcock as the District of Columbia's Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds.{{sfn|BDOA_1906}} He was involved in the beautification of the city and improvements to its infrastructure, but was also tied to allegations of corruption.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=527}} The city's territorial governor, [[Alexander Robey Shepherd]], a Grant appointee, operated aggressively and Babcock and Shepherd were accused of personally profiting from construction projects within the city limits.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=527}} Babcock's supervision included construction of the [[Chain Bridge (Potomac River)|Chain Bridge]] over the [[Potomac River]] and the [[Anacostia Railroad Bridge]].{{sfn|BDOA_1906}} He also supervised the construction of the east wing of the new [[Eisenhower Executive Office Building|State, War and Navy Building]].{{sfn|BDOA_1906}} Babcock retained the Superintendent's position after he was dismissed from the White House in 1876, and served until March 3, 1877, when the Grant administration ended. ====Safe burglary conspiracy (1876)==== On April 15, 1876, Babcock was indicted for involvement in the [[Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration scandals#Safe burglary conspiracy|Safe Burglary Conspiracy]].{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}}{{sfn|McFeely|1974|pp=143-144}} In 1874, Richard Harrington, an Assistant [[United States Attorney]] for [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|Washington, DC]] attempted to [[Frameup|frame]] Columbus Alexander, leader of the Memorialists, an organization critical of Shepherd's management of the city.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}}{{sfn|McFeely|1974|pp=139, 141-142}} Harrington hired dishonest [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] agents to break into the U.S. Attorney's safe, using explosives to make it obvious that a burglary had occurred.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}} To entrap Alexander, the conspirators took materials that were supposedly stolen from the safe to his home at night, intending to give them to him and then later arrest him for their possession.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}}{{sfn|McFeely|pp=141-142}} Alexander thwarted this effort by refusing to answer the door.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}}{{sfn|McFeely|pp=141-142}} At that point, the Secret Service agents arrested two other conspirators who pretended to be the supposed burglars, and had them sign false affidavits implicating Alexander in the burglary.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}} The conspiracy collapsed when the Secret Service agents admitted at Alexander's trial that the charges were false, and Alexander was acquitted.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}} The conspiracy was supposed to have included Babcock, who was said to have wanted to silence Alexander, a prominent Grant administration critic.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=282}} Babcock was allegedly the broker between Harrington and the Secret Service,{{sfn|McFeely|1974|pp=143-144}} but was exonerated of direct involvement, however his continued ties to scandal and corruption increased public pressure on Grant to remove him from the White House.{{sfn|Coffey 2014|page=276}} ==Inspector of lighthouses (1877–1884)== On February 27, 1877 Grant appointed Babcock Inspector of Lighthouses of the Fifth District, a low-profile position that enabled Babcock to earn a living by making use of his engineering skills without drawing undue public attention to himself.{{sfn|BDOA_1906}}{{sfn|Government Printing Office 1898|p=224}} Babcock continued to serve under Grant and his successors [[Rutherford B. Hayes]], [[James A. Garfield]], and [[Chester A. Arthur]]. On August 24, 1882, Arthur appointed Babcock Inspector of Lighthouses for the Sixth District, an appointment he carried out in addition to his Fifth District responsibilities.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}}{{sfn|Government Printing Office 1898|p=224}} [[File:Ulysses S. Grant Trapeze Cartoon Keppler Puck 1880.tif|thumb|180px| alt=Grant, shown in a cartoon as an acrobat hanging from rings, holding up multiple politician/acrobats | ''[[Puck (magazine)|Puck]]'', a Democratic magazine, in 1880 lampooned Babcock and Grant's alleged support of "rings" of corruption among his associates.]] ==Presidential election (1880)== {{further|1880 Republican National Convention|Ulysses S. Grant}} In September 1879, Grant returned from his famous world tour. His popularity was as great as ever and Stalwart Republicans proposed to nominate him for a third term as president. Democrats sought to discredit his previous administration, including his cabinet and political appointees. On February 4, 1880, a color illustration by artist [[Joseph Keppler]] appeared in ''[[Puck (magazine)|Puck]]'' magazine, in which Keppler ridiculed Grant and his associates, including Babcock, for past involvement in corruption.Michael Alexander Kahn, Richard Samuel West (October 2014), [https://books.google.com/books?id=5SfFBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=Puck+(February+4,+1880)&source=bl&ots=c199ZrNBhr&sig=NozHB28t6t5cjuBN5dgw8KT832U&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwizjcGHjLfJAhWImYgKHYCqB4QQ6AEIIzAB#v=onepage&q&f=false What Fools These Mortals Be!], p 49 --- Illustration by Joseph Keppler (February 4, 1880),''Puck'', v. 6, No. 152, pp. 782-783 On May 14, 1880, Connecticut Senator [[William W. Eaton]], a Democrat read a memorial from Davis Hatch, who had been arrested in Santo Domingo in 1868 and was requesting reimbursement for the financial losses he said resulted from his imprisonment.{{sfn|New York Times (May 15, 1880)}} According to Hatch, he was imprisoned on false charges and was going to be released, but Babcock, who visited the island nation in 1869 to secure an annexation treaty, interfered with Hatch's release from prison and was directly complicit in Hatch being falsely sentenced to a five month prison term.{{sfn|New York Times (May 15, 1880)}} Republican Senator [[Roscoe Conkling]] defended Babcock, saying that the Senate investigating committee's majority report fully exonerated him and that Eaton raised the issue only to try giving Democrats an advantage in an election year.{{sfn|New York Times (May 15, 1880)}} In June 1880, the Republicans held their national convention in Chicago. Grant was nominated by Conkling, his main Stalwart supporter. Republicans deadlocked between Grant and the other frontrunners, [[James G. Blaine]] and [[John Sherman]], and selected the [[dark horse]] Garfield as their presidential candidate. Arthur was selected for the vice presidential nomination, and Garfield went on to win the general election, defeating Democratic nominee [[Winfield S. Hancock]]. ==Mosquito Inlet lighthouse and drowning (1883–1884)== [[image:Ponce Inlet Lighthouse 02.jpg|thumb|180px|right|'''Mosquito Inlet Lighthouse''']] The [[Ponce de Leon Inlet Light|Mosquito Inlet Lighthouse]] project started in 1883, and Babcock was the supervising engineer.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}} On June 2, 1884, Babcock and his associates were on duty were aboard the government schooner ''Pharos'' to deliver construction supplies, and were anxious to get to land because a [[subtropical storms|sudden storm]] created hazardous ocean conditions.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}}{{cite web| title=Orville Babcock's Indictment and the CIA Leak Case|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4986394|author=Mike Pesca|date=November 2, 2005}}{{sfn|Government Printing Office 1898|p=224}} The captain decided not to cross over the [[shoal|inlet bar]] during the storm because the construction supplies weighed down the ship, and he feared [[ship grounding|grounding]] it. As the storm worsened, Captain Newins of the nearby ''Bonito'' led seven men in a rowboat to the ''Pharos'' in order to retrieve the passengers.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}} In debating whether to wait out the storm on the ''Pharos'' or try to make land, Babcock told his associates that since Newins and his crew had rowed safely to the ''Pharos'', then they should be able to row to shore on tidal floods created by the storm.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}} After eating their lunch on the ''Pharos'', Babcock and his associates boarded a rowboat and started for the shore. As they approached the inlet bar, [[Swell (ocean)|swells]] capsized the boat several times, and it took on water. Babcock was thrown clear, but another person on the boat attached him to it by a lifeline.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}} The boat and crew were battered by waves, oars, and other debris, and Babcock's lifeline was torn loose from the boat, which resulted in his drowning death. Upon reaching the shore, others who had been in the boat recovered Babcock's body and unsuccessfully tried to [[resuscitate]] him. Three others, including two of Babcock's associates, were also killed; the bodies of Babcock's associates, Levi P. Luckey and Benjamin F. Sutter, were recovered several days later, but the body of the fourth victim, a member of the boat's crew, was not found.{{sfn|Garmon_2009}}{{cite news |date=June 27, 1884 |title=The Mosquito Inlet Disaster: Captain Anderson's Account of the Drowning of Gen. Babcock and Mr. Luckey |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/87230746/ |newspaper=Washington Evening Star |location=Washington, DC |page=4 |subscription=yes}} The lighthouse construction project continued after Babcock's death, and was completed in 1887. ==Historical reputation== Scholars note Babcock's high class standing at West Point, engineering skills, and bravery during the American Civil War.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=78}} Babcock also has been noted positively for his association with the antislavery views of the [[Radical Republicans]], and for his dealings with [[African Americans]] from a position of equality, a trait which was uncommon for the white people of his era, even those who opposed slavery. Historians also make positive mention of Babcock's post-White House career, noting that he served for eight years as a government lighthouse inspector and engineer, and did so capably and honestly. However, historians are critical of Babcock's political power as Grant's White House military aide, shielded by Grant, and not subject to resignation.{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|pp=78, 527}} Historians are also highly suspicious of Babcock's unauthorized Santo Domingo annexation pre-agreement. His reputation was also marred by his involvement in the Gold Ring, the Whiskey Ring, and the Safe Burglary Conspiracy. Most historians agree that Babcock betrayed Grant while President, and remain perplexed at Grant's loyalty to his wartime comrade, including Grant's unprecedented White House deposition on Babcock's behalf. In defending Babcock, Grant was not fully candid with the truth in his own testimony, probably to protect his family and his presidency from further scandal. With Babcock's reputation largely narrowed to observations about his corruption, loyalty to Grant, and wartime bravery, historians are generally not able to consider him in a wider context because he did not author an autobiography, nor has he been the subject of an extended biography. Historian [[William McFeely]] criticized Babcock for ignoring ethical values in the spirit of opportunism and personal gain.{{sfn|McFeely|1981|p=340}} On November 22, 2016, [[Mississippi State University Libraries]] announced the digitalization of Babcock's private diaries.{{sfn|MSU Libraries digitize Civil War diaries and letters}} Babcock's diaries are part of Mississippi State University Libraries' Ulysses S. Grant Digital Collection.{{sfn|MSU Libraries digitize Civil War diaries and letters}} Babcock's diaries began in 1863 during the height of the [[American Civil War]], including his perspective on the [[Vicksburg campaign|siege of Vicksburg]] and his wartime experiences in Kentucky, Ohio, Tennessee, and Virginia.{{sfn|MSU Libraries digitize Civil War diaries and letters}} The diary collections also includes his famous post-war visit to Santo Domingo in 1869 serving as President Grant's special agent and personal secretary.{{sfn|MSU Libraries digitize Civil War diaries and letters}} The collection includes Babcock's supplementary materials of speeches, correspondence, and newspaper clippings.{{sfn|MSU Libraries digitize Civil War diaries and letters}} The Mississippi State University Libraries said that Babcock's brokerage of the annexation of Santo Domingo, "began what became a string of controversies and scandals surrounding Babcock and his position as aide to the President."{{sfn|Orville Babcock Diaries}} The scandals culminated in Babcock's involvement in the Whiskey Ring, indictment for tax fraud in 1875, and corruption trial in St. Louis in 1876.{{sfn|Orville Babcock Diaries}} Throughout these scandals President Grant gave Babcock his confidence.{{sfn|Orville Babcock Diaries}} According to presidential historian [[Charles W. Calhoun]], Babcock emerged as Grant's "political [[majordomo]], if not his jackel."{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=78}} Grant's Secretary of State [[Hamilton Fish]] said Babcock "has brains & very many excellent & gentlemanly qualities but is spoiled by his position & a want of delicacy & consideration for the official responsibilities & proper authority (official) of civilians."{{sfn|Calhoun|2017|p=78}} ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|American Civil War}} * [[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]] * [[Bibliography of the American Civil War]] * [[Bibliography of Ulysses S. '''Pauline Léon''' (28 September 1768 – 5 October 1838), was a radical organizer and [[Feminism|feminist]] during the [[French Revolution]].
==Biography== Léon was born to chocolate makers Pierre-Paul Léon and Mathrine Telohan in [[Paris]] on 28 September 1768. Léon was one of six children. Her father died in 1784, after which time Léon helped her mother with the chocolate business in exchange for room and board. She was also responsible for helping to raise and support her siblings. It is believed that she became a political radical after witnessing the execution of leaders of a bread riot.
On 6 March 1792 she addressed the Legislative Assembly on behalf of Parisian women, suggesting that a female militia be formed so that women could protect their homes from counter-revolutionary assaults. In July 1791 she signed the petition at the [[Champ de Mars, Paris|Champ de Mars]]. Léon was a founder of the [[Society of Revolutionary Republican Women]] (''Société des Républicaines-Révolutionnaires'') along with [[Claire Lacombe]] and became its president on 9 July 1793. Léon and Lacombe both held strong hatred towards [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette|Lafayette]], mostly due to his wartime opinions and actions. The ''Société'' only lasted for about a year before authorities shut it down. She was also a leader of the Femmes Sans-Culottes in 1793. She also was a frequenter of the [[Cordeliers]] Club. At age 29, she married [[Jean Théophile Victor Leclerc|Théophile Leclerc]], the leader of the ''[[Enragés]].'' They were later arrested together, but held separately in the Luxembourg prison from April to August, 1794.
Little is known about Léon's later life. She died at home in Bourbon-Vendée on 5 October 1838.
==References== *{{cite web | last=Fairweather | first=Maria | coauthors= | title=Femininity as well as fraternity in France 1789 | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/3655522/Femininity-as-well-as-fraternity-in-France-1789.html | date=27 Sep 2006 | work= | publisher=telegraph.co.uk | accessdate=2009-06-01 }} *{{cite book |title=The women of Paris and their French Revolution |last=Godineau |first=Dominique |last2=Streip |first2=Katherine |year=1998 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=0-520-06719-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vevlRZYwCTsC&dq=Pauline+L%C3%A9on |accessdate=2009-06-01 }} *Darline Gay Levy, Harriet Branson Applewhite, Mary Durham Johnson. [https://books.google.com/books?id=wfTn6ga2Kw8C&dq=Levy,+Applewhite,+Johnson.&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Women In Revolutionary Paris, 1789-1795'']. University of Illinois Press. 1981.
